23190202.review:
Le meilleurs des 3 ReBirth sans conteste.

Pour être franc j'avais rushé le 2, que je trouvais trop similaire au premier, ce qui est gênant pour un jeu basé en grande partie sur du farm, sans compter les personnages que je trouvais moyens (les CPU Candidates).
Toutefois, ce 3ième est largement au dessus. Plus de nouveautés (sans non plus trop forcer), de nouveaux donjons majoritairement plus grands, quelques systèmes améliorés etc etc...
Si vous avez fait les 2 premiers vous restez en territoire connu, si c’est votre premier, c'est un bon choix, bien que vous perdrez certaines références et blagues.

Gampelay :
Hyperdimension Nep.... 3 c'est quoi ? C'est un RPG et Visual Novel. Des bases de gampelay RPG et une aventure qui se lit façon LN avec des plans fixes, quelques animations de personnages et des dialogues.
Le côté RPG est en tour par tour, simple d'accès, presque similaire au précédent. Si ça peut sembler tactique à première vu, en réalité on a le même problème que les précédents, à savoir : les combats le sont réellement moins. On va souvent spammer la même chose, et on se retrouve vite à s'apercevoir que le système de bouclier est toujours aussi mal foutu car la jauge de vie descend quasiment aussi vite que la jauge de bouclier (qui une fois vide permettrait éventuellement de faire plus de dégâts) dans la majorité des cas. Donc si au début on s'amusera sur les différentes attaques break/crush/rush,  plus tard on spammera rush pour sortir des grosses attaques spéciales (exe drive) pour aller plus vite. Compte tenu du fait qu'on est limité dans nos choix d'attaques (selon la puissance de ces dernières), on ne s'attardera pas trop non plus sur les dégâts physiques, magiques, élémentaires etc, pour contrer les faiblesses des ennemis car le jeu possède un farm très prononcé. Donc à moins de changer votre liste d'attaques toutes les 30 secondes (pour pas grand chose en plus)...
On a sinon toujours le système de changement de donjon, qui modifiera le contenu des coffres ainsi que les boss (et  uniquement les boss cette fois-ci) selon les "plans" craftés.
Le mode Stella Dungeon est de retour, un mini rpg au sein du jeu lui-même, avec un personnage qui ira vous chercher des ressources pour vos craft, des "plans" de craft ou encore d'autres types d'items. Si ça se justifiait sur une console portable, reste que sur PC ça devient très long comme mini jeu, car il se base sur le temps réel. Plusieurs secondes à plusieurs minutes voir heures pour  que votre personnage finisse ses donjons, via un des DLC ce sera 1 secondes par étage.... vous aurez des milliers d'étages à parcourir... M'enfin, ça reste un min jeu sympathique.
Notons qu'avec les DLC inclus il y aura plus de contenu, donjon et un Colisée bien rempli. Colisée qui cette fois sera mieux équilibré que celui du 2, dont les lvl de mobs ne rimaient strictement à rien (des mobs lvl 50 pouvait vous poser plus de problèmes en étant soi-même lvl 99 que d'autres mobs lvl 80 par exemple).


Histoire :
Honnêtement, j'ai trouvé l'histoire de cet opus clairement meilleurs que les précédent, et surtout que le 2.  Enfin, c'est pas tant l'histoire, mais surtout l'humour qui est beaucoup plus présent et drôle. Le personnage de Plutia en est d'ailleurs souvent à l'origine, meilleurs perso de la série pour ma part, que ce soit elle ou sa forme de déesse, Iris Heart, très particulière. Le scénario est assez long de base, et beaucoup plus long et drôle avec les DLC, qui cette fois-ci sont majoritairement doublés. Beaucoup de scènes secondaires en bonus qui valent le coup et donnent lieu à un peu mieux connaitre les personnages secondaires/DLC.
On a d'ailleurs un très gros casting,  et beaucoup d’interaction entre chacun, ce qui rend le jeu beaucoup plus vivant contrairement à certains passages des précédents opus. Ça fait réellement plaisir de voir tout le monde, et de les voir parler entre eux.
De nouveaux méchants (et mobs aussi) feront leur apparition, ainsi que quelques anciens.

Sons :
Niveau son, c'est dans la même veine que les autres, des musiques qui font le taf, des dialogues doublés (choix jap/us) façon anime, des sons +/- sympathiques et qui prêtent à sourire ou au contraire qui agacent.

Visuel :
3D très simple, ça reste joli, et agréable, mais c'est loin d'être une bête graphique. Cependant les passages VN sont toujours aussi beaux, détaillés et propres, avec le même système d'animation.
On notera quelques ralentissement à l'entrée des donjons.

Globalement :
C'est un jeu qui demande un minimum de culture japanimaion/jeux vidéo pour vraiment être apprécié.  Il faut aussi ne pas être allergique à l'aspect Kawaii/moe (mignon), ainsi qu'au farm pour le côté RPG. Car oui, si vous voulez vraiment compléter à fond le jeu, vous en aurez pour des heures et des heures de farm. Je pense notamment au côté vestimentaire, les items sont beaucoup trop cher à mon goût (plusieurs Millions pour certains), ce qui vous nécessitera de farmer bêtement pour l'argent, l'xp et les ressources en tout genre. Le soucis étant que vous spammerez des heures la même touches avec la touche LB enfoncé pour passer les animations. Pas franchement trépidant. Si sur certains jeu ça passe bien, le gameplay des Hyperdimensions ne le rend pas très festif...
J'ajouterais aussi que certains éléments d'interface sont quelques fois irritant. Par exemple le fait de ne pas voir directement la liste des donjons dans une zone, plutôt que passer par le menu et l'onglet encyclopédie (népédia), c'est un poil énervant quand vous cherchez à farmer certaines ressources dans un lieu précis. Y'a d'autres petits trucs comme ça qui paraisse minime, mais sont gênant dans un tel contexte de farm, surtout compte tenu du grand nombre de zones, mobs et drops possibles.... 
M'enfin, de manière général ça reste un jeu intéressant, assez drôle et plutôt joli pour l'aspect VN. Si vous n'avez fait aucun jeu de la série, celui-ci est le meilleur et le plus développé, mais vous ne comprendrez peut être pas toutes les blagues. Si vous avez fait les précédents et avait apprécié, vous êtes en territoire connu, alors n'hésitez pas car je maintiens que c'est de loin le  plus agréable des 3, peut être aussi le plus long avec ses DLC inclus qui ajoutent énormément de contenu et scènes bonus.
À noter que si vous avez vu l'anime, ce dernier reprend dans les grandes lignes un partie de cet opus.

Les points forts :
+ VN très joli
+ gros casting
+ pas mal d'améliorations et quelques ajouts
+ plus drôle et long que jamais
+ beaucoup de contenu en tout genre
+ certains personnages très réussi
+ Donjons globalement plus grands, 

Les points faibles :
- Farm bête et méchant toujours aussi prononcé...
- .... en parti dû à un gameplay qui montre encore une fois rapidement ses limites
- pas de grosses nouveautés/changement non plus
- certains challenges ridiculement long (pour obtenir des bonus +/- intéressants)
- quelques ralentissement et aliasing prononcé malgré une 3d techniquement simple.

22912385.review:
[h1] 个人情况[/h1]
全结局+全成就通关实际60小时（在线时间47小时），共计3周目，人物等级全部600+，Nep等级686级[spoiler] 一看就是偷懒开了dlc的[/spoiler]

[h1] 个人评价[/h1]
rb3是整个rb系列里最先开始玩的，在玩rb3的过程中也玩过rb1和2，不得不说，在三部正作中，rb3在UI、战斗设计、剧情这些方面都表现的十分出色。可以说，rb3是整个系列中我最喜欢的一部。
首先是UI。菜单和前两作有非常大的区别，我个人认为是漂亮了不少，而且整体看上去没有之前两作的模糊的感觉。
然后是战斗设计。给我印象比较深的一个地方就是rb1和2的EXE槽需要每次进副本后自己重新攒，且SP值不能通过平A的方式回复。但是rb3在这方面有非常大的改进，平A回蓝我至少认为比之前的方式科学了不少。
然后是剧情。rb1和rb2和3的剧情算是完全脱节，不过还算轻松；rb2的剧情感觉比较沉重，也稍微影响了我推rb2的进度；而rb3的剧情整体来说是相当轻松愉快的，Nep和噗噜噜全程造笑点，玩了3周目还是感觉特别有趣。[spoiler] 讲道理为啥不给IF吃茄子的event加CG= =[/spoiler]
另外爬塔小游戏比rb2好了很多。强烈建议购买dlc，然后开启爬塔的两项功能。
总体来说，抛去地雷社自己的游戏性的问题，这个游戏还是值得日呆爱好者玩的。rb系列的话，即使没玩过前两部，直接从第三部玩也是完全没有问题的。
总体评分：9.4/10（这0.6分我就扣在最后那丧心病狂的百合度成就上。。。Exam Location的怪都快被我撸平了）

[h1] 额外的话[/h1]
之前是看番入坑的，后来[spoiler] 先是玩了盗版然后[/spoiler]等到打折就rb全系列购入了。慢慢地我也被这个游戏的人设和剧情吸引了——尽管这个游戏的剧情看着还是比较老的套路。
玩的多了，也想了一些别的事情。（这些事情并没有联系实际的游戏厂商）游戏中的女神们永远不会老去，在我看来却是相当残酷的一件事。对她们来说时间是静止的，她们看着周围的朋友长大（比如游戏中的IF和Compa），如果想的更久一点，朋友们也许之后会老去，会去世，而她们则在永恒的时光中继续活着，不会有任何容貌的变化。我之前看过一个镜音连的本子（绝对是全年龄向的），本子里镜音连作为一个家用的机器人，陪伴男主人公从小长到大，直至男主人公去世，连的外貌从未发生变化，原先的他对于主人公来说是一个哥哥，后来是生活中的挚友，再到主人公生命的最后，连一直陪伴在身边，却只能看着主人公去世。不会死去——也许就是一种诅咒吧，你必须活着，看着你生命中的重要的人来了又走，而你无可奈何，只能继续自己的路。
我想在此引用一句话，也是在玩了这个游戏后联想到的：

I will tell you a secret. The Gods envy us. They envy us because we're mortal, because any moment might be our last. Everything is more beautiful because we're doomed.
（我告诉你个秘密。上帝嫉妒我们。他嫉妒我们，因为我们会死去，因为任何时刻都有可能是我们人生的终点。因为我们会死去，世间万物在我们的眼中显得更为美丽。）

不管怎么样，对于我们来说最为珍贵的还是我们有限的生命。

唉……为啥我想到了这些呢……也许我该去玩玩rb1放松下自己了

[spoiler] 果然对于我这种工科生来说我最适合写实验报告而不是评测……全篇看下来干巴巴的[/spoiler]

22650117.review:
Having put nearly 100 hours in to this game, gotten the true ending and seen most of what it has to offer, I can say this is my favorite of the Rebirth series and can very much reccomend to fans of anime, moe, and JRPGs. 

Gameplay is more or less the same as in Rebirth 1 and 2. The combat system isn't incredibly deep, but it works and is fun enough (though I still feel the Break chain of attacks is relatively useless). HDD attacks feel a bit more balanced and not nearly as broken as in Rebirth 1. 

Story wise, though the Neptunia games have never had strong stories, but this one feels the best to me. It follows Nep as she is transported to another dimension, the world of the 1980's game industry, which is a novel idea and leads to fun geeky jokes about the era. The characters have always been what drives the Neptunia games, and this one brings back nearly every previous character in some form, which I adore. 

I found the game relatively easy for most of the main story, but that post game content, dungeons, and Colliusum battles require strategy and will kick your ass if you aren't prepared, which I really like. It's an appreciated difficulty bump for more hardcore players. 

If I had complaints, the biggest one is the continued recycling of dungeons and enviroments. There are only a handful of dungeon layouts, and "new" dungeons are simply old ones with a new enemy coat. This was a problem in Rebirth 1 and 2 and it's a bit irritating it coninues here. The required amount of level grinding is also very grating. 

But overall, Rebirth 3 is my favorite of the Rebirth games and I don't regret putting in the time. Had a lot of fun! Must play for fans of Nep Nep. 

Live Long and Nep Nep~

22557425.review:
*Re-Review*
Having cooled down some, I've decieded to change my review of this game. I previously gave it a thumbs down, and while I've changed that to a thumbs up, I wouldn't exactly 'recommend' this game.
The gameplay is identical to the previous two games, however there is a great deal more talking in this game, and that's saying a lot considering the amount of chit-chat the other games had to offer.
The characters are what really sink this game for me. They range from 'annoying' to 'insufferable' to 'I really wish this game had a Conquest ending so I could personally murder Plutia and Vert'.
I say with absolutly no hyperbole or jest that there were many times during this game where I experienced genuine physical and mental pain. I'd have to stop playing and try to take my mind off of the game for a while before I could even consider coming back to it.
Still, if you enjoyed the other games, you'll probably get some enjoyment out of this one. Just give some thought to buying the DLC, as that's the only way to have any of the Human/Maker characters available to use.
I look forward to the day where we get a Neptunia game that puts less focus on these one-note CPUs, and instead puts the interesting 'side' characters in the limelight.

22442210.review:
Third installment of the neturnia game series released on steam, now it's hard not to openly compare it to the other two before it but so I won't really try, sorry. As far as game difficulty goes its in between the first and second one, the first Re:birth being the hardest and the second being the easiest.
The easiest point of this game is the shear number of characters you get though DLC (which appears be to DLC mostly if you have saves from the previous games rather then buying) outside of the DLC characters it has the smallest cast of playable characters being only the CPU's, (so take it as you want on the DLC characters being bad by making it easier or good to make up for the lack of characters).
Combat system is the same as the previous two with a few diffrences, first off collusium battles are easier now with the monsters being less OP, second off you are given the option of switching KO'd character with there back character, and third, the EX system of the game for combat has been drastly changed, rahter then a shared EX gadge that is shared by the party it is based on the individual characters SP, alsong with those changes SP regenerates a little per hit and all characters have there SP locked at 1000 (no increasing it this game). Along that some line of though I want to add this means you can't spam HDD all the time, your SP doesn't recover when you leave a dungeon, it only recovers from battle or items, but a small plusside (for the DLC characters at least) everyone has an HDD action, or rather none CPU's have Awakening, more or less a super sayain golden aura with boosted stats.
Music is still more or less the same with a few plans that can let you change the music (but only the default or a single alt.) 
Another new addition (Which can be really annoying if your a completionist) is a challange system, basicly you do something a number of times and you unlock stuff (mostly small stat ups with the final level of the challanges being a large stat up, but also some plans), the ploblem here is that some of these are beyond annoying such as one challange where you have to run away from battle, the final level of the being run away from battle 3000 times (and again just one of several) and also it only applies to the active characters (meaning for the one were you have to walk around the map for so many meters you have to do with ALL the characters to competly complete it).
Story wise you'll see a lot of similarity between the anime version with some base setting from the second game (and somehow a lot of refrensing to the first). The story was good and had a lot of good build-up with a bit of acualy game history in it (you'll more or less see the game industries history be built up and refrenced a lot, specially with processors for the CPU you unlock frequently at the start of new chapters). Fans of the series most likly already know that Plutia is a main character so lots of great stuff to expect (Including a priceless scene between Iris Heart, IF, and Arfoir).
Overall tone of the game feels more like the first one with the more wacky and sillyness that you've come to love (or might come to love) from the series and managing to mix in nicely a somewhat serious tone channeling more of the same feel with the first Re:birth but with a lot more fourth wall breaking in this, to a point where even some of the villians do it.
Overall if your a fan of the neptunia series, or wanting to play a less intensive/serious RPG this is a good game to get and unlike the second Re:birth without any major game breaking DLC (except an experience booster plan but easy enough to ignore)

22406283.review:
As I accomplished every achievement, and, being a big fan of this game at the same time, I think that I already have enough understanding of the game as a basis to write a review, let's weigh up the pros and cons first:

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ Funny and long storyline, 3 endings for players to choose, a walkthrough would take about 25-40 hours, depending on your choice to enjoy the story and gameplay.
+ Extremely cute characters makes players immerse rapidly into the game.
+ A wide range of varieties of weapons, items and crafts (plans) are provided.
+ Almost impossible to get stuck (because of difficulty) in the game as you can always gain reasonable amount of XP (a.k.a Experience Points) from enemies that have similar strength as you.
+ Pretty soundtracks can be found here.
+ Well-designed CGs.

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Without achievement guides, it is too easy to miss important items that are necessary for further accomplishments in the game.  This problem was even more serious in earlier Neptunia games. It is recommended to read the guide carefully before starting the game if you want to get as many achievements as possible. Not so much of a big deal as a disadvantage, but still, better to be aware of missable events ^^.

As I mentioned, I’m a sincere fan of this series, so I’ll try to cover as many general aspects as I can possibly think of:

    This game, which can be called HDN re birth 3 (on PC) or Victory (on PS3) for short, is a tactical role-playing game in which players take control of 4 characters both in the front line and the rear line (meaning 8 in total). This makes this latest product different in a more catchy way, probably easier to get the gist of the gameplay compared to the 2 earlier Neptunia games; for new players of HDN, I suggest you to play this first (like me), because this one gives less penalty compared to the 2 earlier ones. When a character dies, for example, in HDN Victory, the system still allow switches between the K.Oed character and the rear character, while in others you need to revive the dead before doing so, also, you have all the characters from the earlier games to use, and so on…….. but don't worry, the story in this game is settled completely differently from the earlier ones, only the same characters remains
.
    However, sometimes you will still face challenges, in this case, there are two ways: 
Develop a strategy or to train characters by fighting monsters from time to time. You can slay bosses which are difficult to beat at the first encounter more easily with the 2nd solution, but in my case for example, I always try to beat the boss with strategies in spite of being difficult, which wine and dines my own tactical strategy ^^, and well, sometimes this takes time -.- .

    About the characters, well, let's say that you will never have enough with them, their cuteness is really, unbeatable (even I cannot resist >^<), in my opinion, this is a special and important feature for this series, every character is different, which is why the use of strategy becomes interesting here [spoiler]excluding the OPed histoire[/spoiler].

    Speaking of items, weapons and crafts, we have an abundant amount of which in this game, this keeps leveling up the character’s ability as players upgrade their equipments while training. Crafts, which are called plans in this game, play an extremely important role in this game, some plans gives you extremely powerful weapons while others provide very useful items, many maps even require the corresponding plan to be unlocked, therefore, as far as I’m concerned, it is important to sometimes pause from advancing the storyline in order to get some plans done, this makes the gameplay a lot easier. There are different ways to get a plan done, some requires you to gather items from enemy drops, others needs you to gather ingredients in the field of a dungeon...... et cetera. Don't worry about getting bored, even exploring them can be fun ^^.

    Soundtracks and CGs in this game are also well done. Idea Factory, together with Compile Heart, created its own style of character’s painting design which is genuinely unique, you can’t find anime artworks with similar ingenuity of manga creation elsewhere. Soundtracks are generally a good background support to the gameplay, although I can’t think of anything extraordinary, these soundtracks are special for me personally in terms of melody, hopefully you will enjoy them as well ^^.

     About potential bugs, I don't think that I encountered more 5 bugs after 82 hours of gameplay, so for me, the gameplay is pretty solid. I'm sorry for players who often experiences crashes in game, I am not really helpful here...

    Thank you for reading this review, I hope that this did give you a general idea on the system of the game as well as the main features. However, I have to say that even if it did, it remains only a vague introduction, there are tons and tons of things which only you can discover in this game, no descriptions can really work for HDN series. The only way to learn and have a deep understanding of it is to give it a try ^^.

Hyperdimesdion Neptunia Re;Birth3 V Generation is the sequel to the last game, Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth2 Sisters Generation. However, the stories did not connect to each other.

After I played the last two games, I like this the most because of a lot of new features that added to this game. And even more content than ever. You can easily put a lot of hours to this game. Trust me. Now lets talk about advantage and disadvantages.

Advantages:
-+1 Combo: You can perform 5 combos right now and another EX Finishes.
-Easier to explore Stella's Dungeon: Instead of explore the actual dungeon in Re;Birth2, this game become "Areas". One area includes a lot of items. Easier to finish. And you can deploy her while you are in dungeon too.
-Easier to acquire plans: Plans that you will get you will find less plans because Stella will find it for you.
-Explore the actual Nation: Instead of every nation in the same map, you have the large map that includes nations and each natio have it's own map.
-More dungeons than ever: Means you can grind easier.
-Leader effect: You will get bonus stats based on what character is the leader.
-Better looking menu: Why I frogot about this. It's easier to understand.

Disadvantages:
-Some crashes and framerate drops: Still better than the second game. But in first game I got zero crashes and framerate drops. Especially wheh I fight the CPUs I got bad framerate drops. Even I have an awesome rig.
-Grinding like the previous games: The way Neptunia was meant to be played.
-More useless plans: You know what, I hate this. More features and also more useless plans. The +1 combo I said above should use plans...... for each character.  Leader effect I also said above should use plans too. No individual EXE Skills, only the couple and frontline EXE Skills was given through the story. Why? BECAUSE YOU NEED A F*CKING PLAN TO UNLOCK FOR EACH CHARACTER. F*CK THIS.
-Now SP and EXE Drive gauge become one: Means hitting enemies refils SP gauge because they remove the actual EXE Drive Gauge. Means Ex finishers based on the amount of SP you have, EXE Skills consumes SP(1SP bar means 250 SP=1EXE for previous games).Many like it. But I don't.

Overall: This game is superior to the first two games(Oh and also U. forget about it, hugely lack of content). This game has a lot of content that you can't get enough. I recommend this a lot.

22354652.review:
Well the game the first 2 remakes were based on has finally hit steam. Did you play the first two and like them? Well this game is what they're based off of, well the original PS3 version (pre-remake) anyway. It's got some tweeks to it to be certain but it almost feels like an episodic game at this point. 
Combat is fast and fluid, has some customization to it and is fun to do. The cutscenes are as basic as the previous ones, slightly animated portraits that talk at eachother infront of static backgrounds. 

The music is funky, the character visuals and animations look great, backgrounds are like a budget PS2 era game (as usual). Gameplay is broken into long sessions of dialogue dumps, then you can hunt for more chatter on the overworld map, then there's the dungeons where ....I'm sure there's a review here that dives into this better than me, there's a lot you can do to dungeons to alter them with enemies and item drops. 

There's not a lot to say on it since a lot of the visuals are reused, as is music, animations and the like. It's as dumb and fun as before, just with more polish. The human characters are given more balance by being able to power up like the CPUs, so you have a better selection of characters this time....and a lot of them to be sure. Every character you've ever seen in the series so far. 

Seriouness aside, I enjoy the nerdy console/game jokes they sling around a bunch, getting more of them than I'd like to admit. The humor is dumb, silly and cliche at parts. Fanservice? Not so into that but it's there if you like it! 

My complaint lies in the imbalance of the DLC characters, it's awful. Some are insanely OP because of gear, and others have sub par gear and you can't upgrade them through much of the story. Ex: Kid IF has really strong weapons that were great for 2 chapters, regular IF has crap weapons and even weapons bought later had her lacking behind any other character by a long shot. But then you get Histy or the like and they have vastly superior gear to anyone and everyone. At level 1 they'll best your level 30+ characters in damage. 

Fun game, more of the same and hopefully now that they're done remaking they'll have more variety in the series. 

IF is the best character still, just FYI, the main character really. I dunno why they keep calling it "Neptune" when the only smart one of the bunch is kickin' ass and moving the party of GODS along.

21938547.review:
玩了重生1，没玩2，直接玩的3，跟1代相比，内容丰富了不少。
exe技能现在是攒sp条释放，消耗sp值，加入了更多cp的exe技能，前阵最多可以有4人了，并且有4人的exe前排技能。
剧情上长度也增长了，坏结局其实挺难出的，因为大多数玩家应该有event都会点进去看吧，真结局的话要做出6个地图并分别看剧情，这个的话略麻烦，特别是最后一个地图需要的素材是在主线最后一个地图才有的，要退出主线地图把地城做出来。免费的dlc里的人物都有各自的故事可以看，挺有趣的，不过这些人物的战力一般，就那四个贤者（还是先知？没玩过2，只认识史书）还不错，前中期可以用。
刷塔小游戏不买dlc的话，挺烦的，耗时太长了，买了唯一的收费dlc之后就快得飞起了。
想要全收集的话还是需要刷刷刷，但是这代的隐藏变成了顶砖块，一个地图有五个，只有一个里面有东西，随机的，而且有没有衣服饰品之类的也是随机的，所以一个地图要反复刷，简直。。。而且这种回合制rpg说实话感觉通了主线之后再刷没什么乐趣，掌机上还好，随时都可以拿出来玩，电脑上刷感觉有点浪费时间，不过这代在通了之后还有特殊的剧情和地图，也算增加了一点趣味性。总之逼死强迫症（幸好我不是）。
不知道是我电脑的问题还是游戏本身的优化问题，进地图会卡，战斗也会卡，战斗完之后还会出现人物在地图上的位置不对的bug，有时会到地图上显示去不了的地方，不过能走回来，这bug出现几率还不低。
人物模型确实感觉没什么进步，不够精细。
总之日呆必买，喜欢萌和日常百合的朋友不要错过。

如果你是属于日漫萌系爱好者并且不追求大作画面级别那种游戏要求的话可以入手这作玩下.
典型日式RPG操作简单也不难，战斗系统也比较有趣按键连招不会让你觉得无聊，剧情方面由于有杀必死+萌要素+CV+各种梗吐槽基本很少会直接跳过，这样就比较好的去了解这作.

最后吐槽下就是这作最好是如果你日文好的话建议打下日文文本补丁，游戏是固定全英文文本（什么你说汉化？也有不过质量比较差，乱码+DLC没翻+机翻，除非是日英都不懂，那么我是不建议打汉化的）键盘设定比较麻烦建议有手柄最好，其次是游戏配置要求其实不算很高，至少比官方要求还低一些

21779447.review:
[h1]Once again, I have left writing this review for far too long[/h1]
Ironically, like my review of Neptunia 2, which was quite delayed, I am once again going to be reviewing Neptunia 3 mostly as a sequel, though I shall also try my best to review Neptunia 3 as it's own game, also akin to my review of Neptunia 2.

[b]Is it the best game ever?[/b]
Nah, still Valkyrie Profile. I doubt anything will change this fact for a long time.

[b]But is it a good game?[/b]
Definitely. Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 3 Victory Generation is a brilliant game and well worth playing if you're even remotely tempted.

[b]I'm still lazy, and writing Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 3 Victory Generation everytime I wish to refer to the game is arduous and word count consuming, so Neptunia 3 it shall be.

So, what's new?[/b]
Well, not alot, really.

To my knowledge, Neptunia V was the first in the series to use the current "freeish movement" battle format that has been used in the rereleases, the Re;birth series, so while a slightly updated rerelease of V nicely rounds out the first three games of the series, it does feel a little silly. 

Not that I care, I'm not buying a Ps3 just for Neptune. (I totally would, though).

That being said, the Re;birth series [i]did[/i] also port Neptunia to the Vita and consequently, the PC.

While I stand by my statement of "not alot, really", this isn't necessarily a bad thing. The format of the game they have works, can be quick for that post-story grinding and doesn't feel like a chore when you're near the end. It's good.

[b]So, Tom, what [i]is[/i] new? Tell us properly this time.[/b]
Ok, alright, I'm sorry.

The story is new, obviously. It's quite good, as well. I thoroughly enjoyed it, though in my opinion the story of Neptunia 1 is better, the story of Neptunia 3 is still very good, if not a little better in some aspects. With a new story comes new characters. Some are "new", while others are actually totally new. Plutia, Lady Iris Heart, is fantastic and shall hopefully be a staple character in the future games [Spoiler](She's not in VII ;<)[/spoiler].

With a new story, we get a new dimension, but unlike Neptunia 2 to Neptunia 1, Neptunia 3 is set in the same universe as Neptunia 2, and is a direct sequel to it. This new dimension is effectively gaming in the late 1980's and early 90's, and it's awesome. Fun fact, this makes some of the characters in it older than my glorious self.

Challenges have been [strike]lifted[/strike] borrowed from Fairy Fencer F, and a little character scaling has been adapted into them. While they don't really do anything important, some of the challenges grant very nice and useful things if you manage to finish them off, but this may take a while.

Neptunia 3 is also the first in the series to use in game cutscenes, albeit very few. They are enjoyable, and a nice break from Visual Novel presentation.

Nepstation! I almost forgot Nepstation. A mock TV show that is inbetween chapters and separate to the plot. 'Tis a fun little breather as well as having extra stuff to do and win.

[b]So, what returns?[/b]
Neptune, obviously, as does her sister and all of the other main cast. A good chunk of side characters also make an appearance but the Oracles are on holiday, or something. 

Stella's Dungeon also makes a return; it's bigger and better and less invoking of your ire if you have any plans to 100% the game's achievements. Doing so will still take a great amount of time, however, and I personally cannot be arsed with that. Despite the length that Stella's dungeon lasts, it always gives you useful things and also gives you some key things, such as Plans for increasing combos.

Other than that, alot of what you will expect from Neptunia returns. The game still retains it's humour, BAMs, optional dungeons, post game content and a large amount of attire for the girls.

You know what else returns? THE SOUND SETTINGS DEFAULT TO MAX. STOP THIS.
[spoiler]They did stop it, finally, in Neptunia VII. They only default to ~35%. Wonderful.[/spoiler]

[b]So what about that port?[/b]
There's... actually extremely little to say here that wasn't already said for Neptunia 2. As aforementioned, sounds still default to max, but other than one seemingly rare game breaking bug that I had, which can be fixed with a little help from Google (I don't know if the developers have fixed it officially at this point), there's nothing new or different.

To be fair, this is a good thing as the port quality of the previous two games was pretty solid and this is no different.

[b]So, what else?[/b]
As with Neptunia 2 to Neptunia 1, all the dungeons and so on look nicer, there's some newer enemies here and there, while the UI and menus all look better and more streamlined.

The resource management has been rearranged a bit; the EXE drive is taking a break for this installment and the mana has been standardised to 1000 at all levels. I like this, skills no longer cost disproportionately high amounts of mana early on, and mana potions are now worthwhile past Chapter 2. Mana also regerates a little between turns, I believe.

The Mana is divided into four chunks, and special moves now use up to all four of those 250 mana chunks to cast, further providing relevance for mana potions. Sadly, nothing else has been rescaled,  combat-wise, so Formation and Coupling Skills are still fairly redundant, the tier 2 super moves are still generally the best, while the AoE supers are still blatantly the strongest. That and Neptunia [i]still[/i] doesn't have a worthwhile final Power attack, though she does feel a little stronger.

[b]Overall[/b]
Much like with the rest of the Neptunia series, I'd happily pay full price for Neptunia 3 and enjoy it for what some may say is too long. As it happens, I once again bought the game on release sale for £13, Yay sales.

I love this series, and as such, have since bought and played alot of the new Neptunia VII on the PS4 [spoiler]which is amazing[/spoiler]. That does mean that I'm unlikely to grant you with another Magnum Opus review for a while, but I'm afraid we shall all have to deal with it.

Also, it must suck to be in your older sister's shadow. Especially when your older sister is so utterly perfect and amazing and there is now twice as much perfection for you to compete with.

21720589.review:
Re;Birth3 V Generation is basically a direct improvement over the previous entries in the series, and in many ways is even superior to the most recent mainline release, Victory 2. The quality-of-life improvements in R;B3 from previous entries are substantial, and the game itself, for those who haven't played Victory, is superb. 

The Neptunia franchise, for those unfamiliar, features fairly standard JRPG gameplay, but the main attraction are the visual-novel-esque story and character interaction segments. In contrast to mk2/R;B2, Victory/RB;3 features a story that is far more about the characters than an overarching plot (though one is present). Most of the time you spend playing the game will probably be spent watching the very colorful cast interact with each other. The initial party (and main characters in this entry) of Neptune, Plutia, and Noire is an excellent combination of personalities that really sells the more slice-of-life atmosphere present in R;B3 compared to its predecessors. I think it really should be mentioned that Kana Hanazawa, who provides the voice for Plutia, is near her best in this game, demonstrating an absolutely masterful range and stellar performance.

Having played and enjoyed all of the main games in the franchise, I personally find Re;Birth 3 to be the most entertaining and fun entry in the series, narrowly beating out even V2. If you have played any of the other games in the series, I strongly encourage you to purchase this game, and if you have not yet played a Neptunia game but are interested in the series I think RB;3 is the best place to start.

21717127.review:
El mas divertido de la trilogia, lejos.

Vuelven los personajes anteriormete vistos con una nueva historia, en una nueva dimension.

Este titulo tiene mucho mas de novela visual que los anteriores, con muchas mas interaccion entre los personajes, ya sean los buenos o los malos. Cargado de mas humor, mas misiones sidestory y mas rejugabilidad que los anteriores, asi mismo es mucho mas fluido el desplazamiento por las masmorras o el combate, no se requiere tanto el quedarse matando criaturas en un mapa en particular para avanzar tanto en la historia como para desbloquear accesorios/armas/masmorras/etc, tras renovar el stella´s system, se hace mas entretenido entrar a esa seccion del juego a diferencia de re;Birth 2.

El cambio del sistema EXE o poderes definitivos lo convierte en algo mas tactico las batallas de jefes o duelos en el coliseo, haciendo que sea mas meticulosa la eleccion de los roster, tanto como los que estan de apoyo.

Tiene el sistema como en Fairy Fencer F de progresion con los personajes a medida que hacen cosas en el juego, tales como tiempo con ellos como lideres, batallas ganadas, especiales utilizados, tesoros que encuentras, etc. Con lo que aparte de los niveles o desbloquear poderes con los planos esta incorporacion hace mas "jugable" a personajes que no sueles utilizar.
 
Como positivo adicional... PURURUTO!!!! El personaje con que me he divertido mas en la saga... LEJOS!! hace su aparicion, no tendras que comprarte mas DLC como en re;birth1-re;birth2 para jugar con ella. Como protagonista. Y por si fuera poco CON MAS ABILIDADES!!! (guiño-guiño)

Advertidos, consume mas poder al pc que los anteriores pero creeme, se agradece,

Lo malo podria ser la gran cantidad de masmorras, podrias perderte cuando desbloqueas algunas, saltandote materiales importantes para ciertos planos o incluso no darte cuenta de a donde tienes que ir para continuar con la historia.

Tambien se agradece el gesto en este juego de no tener que comprar tanto DLC para tener el juego full ya que vienen incorporados.

21479140.review:
If you're considering Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth3 V Generation....

That's too hard to type all the time. I'm just going to call the game Nep-Nep 3 from now on.

OK. Nep-Nep 3 is, at its core, a pretty much by-the-numbers JRPG. Fight monsters, level up, fight more monsters, level up, etc.  There's a crafting system wherein you take items gained from battle to make new items, as well as to unlock items to be sold in shops. The battle mechanics are a bit unique, and combine strategic placement of your characters along with combo attacks that add some variety to what would otherwise be pretty stale gameplay.

This game gets most of its fan following from 2 main points. The first is a positively ludicrous amount of fan service. The cast is made up exclusively of cute girls wearing elaborate and often skimpy outfits.  The second is the game's sense of humor. Its main character, Neptune, is extremely self-aware and very genre-savvy. She KNOWS she's in a video game and so do most of the other characters. They make comments about it constantly and they're always breaking the 4th wall, and Neptune will frequently talk directly to the player.

So if you're looking at Nep-Nep 3, you've probably already played the previous games in the series. If you haven't, here's a quick rundown of the setting. The world of Gamindustri is split up into 4 nations--Planeptune, Lastation, Lowee and Leanbox. Each nation is ruled by a goddess, often referred to as a CPU. These goddesses take the beliefs of their people and translate them into formidable combat prowess. They gain this belief, called "shares" by supporting and helping their people. They used to fight each other constantly for domination of Gamindustri. Now they all find themselves as more friendly rivals than bitter enemies (thanks to Neptune's actions in a previous game). If you think all this stuff sounds familiar, that's not by accident. The whole game is an allegory for the entire game industry (Gamindustri, get it?) The nations of Planeptune, Lastation, Lowee and Leanbox are meant to represent the hardware manufacturers Sega, Sony, Nintendo and Microsoft (in that order).  The entire world is littered with references to video games--some subtle, others REALLY blatant) and the whole thing has a vibe of "we changed the names just enough to avoid getting sued".  It's part of the humor though.

If you have not played the first two games, I wouldn't worry about it too much. There's stuff that happens there that will be referenced in this game, but they'll generally explain what they're talking about when that happens.  Also, the games are all pretty similar to each other. The big downside is they recycle a lot of assets from game to game, from enemy types to character models to even entire dungeon maps. To a degree this makes some sense as all the games take place in the same spot, and in a pretty close time frame--so the world really doesn't change much. That said, the appearance of the game is decidedly last-gen.  The character animations are stiff and the models are of a middling quality. (Then again, all 3 of these games are console ports, so that may have something to do with it)

So how can I sum all this up?  Well, if you played Nep-Nep 1 and 2 and enjoyed them, this is more of the same, so you'll like it.  If you didn't care for either of those two games, don't bother.  If you're on the fence but like a funny JRPG that doesn't take itself too seriously, I suggest giving it a go.

21386073.review:
[h1][b]¿QUÉ ES HYPERDIMENSION NEPTUNIA RE;BIRTH 3?[/b][/h1]

Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 3 es el tercer juego de la serie de remakes para PSVITA y PC, un particular JRPG donde tomaremos el control de CPU'S (o diosas) que tienen cierta relación con las consolas del mundo de los videojuegos, donde el humor y pequeños guiños hacia la comunidad gamer son el plato corriente. Entre las novedades tenemos un mejor apartado gráfico, mas personalización que nunca y la simpatía que hace especial esta saga.

[h1][u]LO BUENO[/u][/h1]

• Mucho mejor que su antecesor (Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 2) en todo sentido.

• Modelos en 3D de mayor resolución; renovados menúes y UI.

• Algunas mejoras que hacen mas fácil saber y conseguir objetos del juego.

• Neptune y compañía están de nuevo… alegría.

[h1][u]LO MALO[/u][/h1]

• Caída considerada de frames en algunos dungeons; crasheos aleatorios.

• Mecánicas que no son explicadas debidamente con paciencia.

• A pesar de que el fuerte no es la historia, esta cae mucho hacia los últimos capítulos.


[h1][u]Mi Opinión...[/u][/h1]

Luego de la decepción del segundo remake, estuve con ciertas dudas acerca de este pero considerando que los problemas principales venían por un grupo de protagonistas con poco carisma, la vuelta de las CPU's originales volvería a traer la salsa que caracterizo el primer juego. De hecho, en parte lo hizo con la adición de otro personaje loco, en el buen sentido, que si bien no trae naaaada nuevo es interesante. Molesta en ciertos casos. Con respecto a todo lo demás, si aguantaste 2 juegos y los conoces bien, este no es la excepción salvo algún que otro cambio con respecto a los planes, combos, ingredientes para crear items y demás. En consideración a lo que es la saga, estoy satisfecho. No es EL JRPG que compite directamente contra Final Fantasy, pero tiene su carisma y humor que lo hace de querer.

[B]NOTA:[/b][i] *B-*[/i] – Otra adición de las aventuras de Neptune. Levanto vuelo luego de un antecesor decepcionante, pero no llega a estar a la altura de un genial primer titulo.

Лучшая часть на данный момент. Как в плане сюжета, так и в плане геймплея. Также радует, что в этой части хоть и новое измерение, но Неп-Неп старая.
- великолепная музыка, от которой не болят уши. Её, если надоест, можно даже сменить через крафт.
- переработанная система SP и EXE-драйва. Теперь есть только SP, поделённый на уровни, накапливающийся при атаках и расходующийся на спец-атаки и EXE-драйв. Таким образом не получится копить EXE-драйв одними персонажами, а расходовать другими (как это было в предыдущих частях). И даже хилу придётся участвовать в бою, чтобы не проседать по мане.
- разнообразные боссы. В отличие от 2 части, где Шестёрка успевает конкретно надоесть, здесь с этим дела обстоят гораздо лучше.
- Плутия и её взаимодействие с другими персонажами особенно доставляет.
- в этой части гораздо больше игровых часов и меньше гринда, чем в предыдущих частях, что не может не радовать.

-впрочем, баги и вылеты никуда не делись. Они есть и здесь. Лично у меня самым частым багом было пропадание анимации атак.

21373432.review:
[i]Thumbs up for this hilarious game! Story based game (Visual Novel) with a mix of turn based and fighting game... which is surprisingly interesting at times. In fact, I'm not a man who smiles very often, but I did smile a lot due to this game! :D[/i]
- me, 14th of November 2015

[b]<If you don't want to read all the descriptive and narrative stuff... just scroll down to the lists, but maybe that means that you won't like the game since it has a lot of story>[/b]

So, I hope that you have seen the trailer and a few screenshots before reading this review. This game is a Japanese RPG with its iconic characters. It's a Turn-Based game with Fighting animations. The storry is very funny and if you don't like reading the story and you only want mindless slaughter... leave now.  The game itself is a remake of the PS3 version, I don't know the PS3 version of this game but I do know that the rework from the first game and that one had huge differences.  

It's a port from the PSVita and you feel that, the interface wasn't actually remade for PC Gamers so this version still is PSVita, but enhanced with some mouse support and maybe some additional feature. I ended up playing only with the keyboard the entire time, and remapped part of the NumBlock to fit for combat, movement and navegation. I haven't played with a gamepad but I strongly recommend using one (Most likely Xbox 360 ro Xbox One if you don't want to get in trouble). It also has some optimization issues and has an FPS limit, quite low for my taste actually.

The characters are interesting, the story is funny in a simple way and the combat effects are wonderful and "hype", [i] I want to be punished by HDD' Plutia: Her Ladyship Iris Heart[/i] and you learn a few things... like some body parts in latin or references about the console wars.

The "Plans" system isn't good in my opinion.... most weapons end up being useless before I can even buy them after crafting.... I tend to have unlocked the next tier default weapons and their stats beat them easily. No gain by crafting most weapons (there are exceptions). Only Armor and Ornaments tend to have some utility in this game... the rest is just for decoration. The game isn't that challenging... and you can't actually change it, I have it in hard mode and I still end up slicing the boss with Neptune's special ability. Once again... optimization issues (laggy). The [u]map design[/u]... and the [u]textures[/u] (flooring and maps), they could seriously improve A LOT Some BGM could improve (specially the boss music when fighting the fellow goddesses) The [u]SHARES[/u] system apparently is totally useless... shares get reset after cutscenes or however you want to call them...  I had 100% shares on planeptune and got set to 10% after a storybreak... [b]AWESOME! (NO)[/b] and there are a few more and I will add them once I have meditated a bit.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]

[b]+ + +[/b]
[list]
[*]Interesting/funny characters.
[*]Nep-nep.
[*]Wonderful skill animations
[*]Funny & simple story.
[*]Plenty of outfits to buy and to craft.
[*]You may learn new things related to gaming and gaming culture... also maybe japanese culture.
[*]It's [b]KAWAII![/b]
[/list]
[b]+++[/b]

[b]- - -[/b]
[list]
[*]It's a port and you feel it.
[*]Not or poorly optimized.
[*]Map design and textures are poor.
[*][Personal objection] It's turn-based.
[*]Many plans end up being useless.
[*]The shares system apparently has no impact... atleast it's not friendly.
[*]The game is easy... if you get beaten by an enemy, just grind a bit and you'll beat it in no-time flat... so it usually isn't very challenging.
[*]Some boss-battle music ruining the atmosphere... It rather makes me laugh than feel epic for beating them. (Vs the fellow Goddesses)
[*]The combat system itself is boring in terms of tactics, if not for the animations, I'd say it's too cheap [the system]. Turn-based but without advantages for tactical positioning (except that it's dumb to have all characters right next to eachother, because then AoE's can hit all of them)
[*]27.99 €? No, that's somewhat overpriced... I'd put it on 20€ so atleast reduce it to 25€.
[/list]
[b]- - -[/b]


All in all, I was very happy with the game. I don't regret having bought it.

PS: You want one of those x/10 , right? Well [b]NO![/b]  You can't mathemathically quantify [u]ART[/u], and if you think that you can you're a fool. Go and read or watch [i]Dead Poets Society[/i] and you'll understand.

          4.还有更丰富的剧情，比二代用心多了，紧密而有趣，现在我才玩了3章，都用了10几个小时。 。
但是同样还有缺点:
          众所周知，三代会在进入地图或者战斗有时候会卡崩，而且几率也不小!
          还有就是历代都有的问题！官方没有汉化（这个是小事），还没有日文字幕！导致翻译组翻译效果极差！这个严重差评！
最后.....还有啥说的，买买买，这都不剁手难道不是咸鱼？

20982795.review:
[h1]Neptunia Re;Birth 3[/h1]

This game is a great one. I've played all three Re;Birhths(Which are remakes of the original Neptunia, Neptunia MK2, as well as Neptunia Victory). Although, I kind of regret playing Re;Brith 2. Stay away from that if you can.

[h1]Characters and Story[/h1]

Story wise, this game does not follow after Neptunia Re;birth 1, but it does chronologically take place after the events within Neptunia Re;Birth 2. Re;birth 3 begins with the 4 goddesses, Neptune(Nepu Nepu), Noire, Blanc, and Vert playing a game. As they decide to team on Nepu Nepu to have a greater chance of winning, the game "breaks". Nepgear, Neptune's sister, takes this moment to test out her new "N-gear"(I think that's what it was called), and she tests it upon Neptune so Nepu Nepu can dive into the game and see what is causing the game to be so bugged out. Eventually, after being ratted out for being so lazy dispite being the Goddess of a Nation, Nepu Nepu is forced to go do work for once. How could someone be so mean to my Nepu Nepu!? Anyways, Neptune ends up running into someone and she is then sent to a different dimension where she thinks all is the same, but it's not.

Character wise, I love every single one of them. With the exception of Uni. Uni is a bland, over the top Tsundere.(Noire is a better Tsundere) Neptune is the goddess of Planeptu- I bit my toungue -_- She usually likes to break the 4th wall constantly and she's pretty lazy compared to the hard working tsundere, Noire. Now Noire is the goddess of Lastation and is your typical tsundere. She has a hard time being true about her feelings and Neptune is usually the one to put her in that spot. She's probably my 3rd or 4th favorite character. Vert is the goddess of Leanbox. Vert generally acts like a princess. She has that look, AND that chest to fit the type too. Blanc is the goddess of Lowee. She is the quiet, "I'm going to beat the shit out of you if you make fun of my chest" kind of girl. She's generally like that through out the game.(Though it's pretty funny when Vert constantly teases her about it)

I've only talked about the four main goddesses because I don't want to go into the 20+ playable characters avalible for your pleasure.(Broccoli, Tekken, Mages, and Marvelous AQL are my favorites).

[h1]Battle System[/h1]

Now the battle system is an updated version of the combat system used in the orginal "Hyperdimension Neptunia Victory" and is combination of Breath of Fire V's and Persona's battle system. You go into dungeons and monsters or enemies are placed in certain parts of the dungeon. Now if you strike the enemy before they attack you, you are granted the first turn. This is called a "symbol attack". If the enemy attacks you first, they get the first turn. When you attack an enemy, you have addition attacks to perform. Those being rush, power, and guard attacks. Not only that, but you can swap partners, change forms(non goddesses can only "awaken"), use items, as well as skills. When you are facing an enemy, they have two bars. One for health, one for their "guard". Take out their guard points using "guard" attacks and you are granted the ability to inflict a larger ammount of damage on the enemy. They can regenerate this bar each turn though. Now like Re;Birth 2's combat system, and unlike Re;Birth 1's, you can use 4 party members. The bonus in this game's new battle system, is the ability to use 5 combos, as opposed to 4 in the previous games. Don't let this fool you. Each characters 5th combo slot have to be unlocked via the "remake system" and only certain characters can have a 5th combo slot for the earlier mentioned forms of attack.

I really like the battle system because you have to choose which attacks to use against which enemies and when you use them. An example is trying to use your high costing skills on an enemy who's guard points have not been lowered. This is a stupid idea as you will not do as much damage as if the enemy didn't have any guard. Overall, newcomers will find this battle system difficult for the first 10 minutes of game play. After that, you'll be breezing through it like Nepu Nepu does with her puddings.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Re;Birth 3 features the same map/area mechanics as the previous games. Every area/dungeon is placed on a map. You select the area and are teleported to the corresponding dungeon. A menu opens up if you click on one of the major locations such as Planeptu, I bit my toungue again -_-, Lastation, Leanbox, and Lowee. The menu that opens up allows you to access the shop, museum, Nepstation, as well as the guild. The shop is where you would buy usable, or equipable items. The museum is where you view past cutscenes, unlockable images, as well as soundtracks that are unlocked with the game's progression. The Nepstation is only avalible in Planep- I'm not biting my toungue again... The Nepstation is a bit unique. Each time you visit the Nepstation, you view an event. Now the even is where you either take a "one million Nep quiz", get certain items at discount prices, or to see some extra bit of dialogue. The guild is where you can take up quests, and complete them to earn small rewards. Some quests will have to be completed to progess the game. Every quest has a certain symbol or lettering next to them. This determines whether or not you can repeat them, or if they are story related.

One major aspect of this game, is the "remake system". Through out the game find "plans". Plans are used to alter dungeons, add certain bonus's to your characters, and to add items to the shop. To put these plans in effect, you need to get yourself some of Nepu Nepu's pudding. You actually need to get yourself some "memory". Memory increases are found at certain points in the game. One more major thing to put plans into effect, is materials you find from enemies. Most basic plans will only require low tier monster drops where as more advanced plans require drops from even certain bosses. Don't expect to be able to craft every single plan because you'll never be able to with the limited ammount of memory. You also won't be able to because you're only on your first play through of the game. Which is what I'm about to go into right now.

When you complete a single player game, you're done, that's it. When playing Re;Birth 3, you are able to play "new game plus". Nothing new really happens in new game plus, but you are given more memory with the story quests and events that you come accros in the previous run through of the game. New game plus doens't offer you any new material except for the "good ending" and the "true ending". These can both be done without going into new game plus but you would have to create whole different saves. The reason you would want to do this in new game plus is your character data and items carry over. Got a level 100 Nepu Nepu and a swimsuit but you want to redo the game to get the true ending? Don't worry, new game plus has your back with it's ability to carry over data.

[h1]Achievements[/h1]

The achievements in this game aren't too difficult to get, but they require some grinding to do. You'll find yourself getting half of them by just playing the game, but there are some where they require you to do major grinding like the "lovable achievements". There's not much to talk about the achievements so I'll just end it here.

[h1]After thoughs[/h1]

In the end, was this game worth the $30(31 with DLC)? To me, yes. There's quite a lot to do and it can keep even hard core grinders busy for several hours. I would aim for this game on sale though since it's just SO GOOD for just $12. I totally didn't buy it on sale... Anyways, this game offeres lovable characters, great 4th wall breaking events, as well as relaxing gameplay that the $15 CS:GO would never do. 

10/10 would recommend with Nepu Nepu and her puddings again!

20960758.review:
Ah... Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth3 V Generation... that's a mouthful, huh?

So far, I've enjoyed the two previous  Hyperdimension Neptunia games, and this one is no different.  All three of them are pretty crazy, with unique characters, storylines and plenty of fourth-wall-breaking mayhem.

I'm going to keep it fairly short, but I'll touch upon the pros and cons below.

Pros:
Excellent Voice Acting
Enjoyable, if loosely-connected Storyline
Quite Comedic
Fun & Unique Battle System (To the series)

Cons:
Battles can feel unbalanced at times
It felt like the game was dragging its feet a few times
The ending seemed to come out of nowhere

I very much enjoyed most of the game, from the fun battle system, to the corny fourth-wall-breaking jokes.  I would highly recommend this game to anyone who thinks they could enjoy it, based on this review.  I tried to be as spoiler-less as possible.

As always, needs more Nep-Nep.

20945844.review:
作为一款经典的JRPG，于2015年10月底登陆PC平台的《重生3》没有让玩家们失望，现如今已经过去了4个月，《超次元ACT：海王星U》也即将登陆Steam。15年可谓是海王星系列作品“井喷”的一年：PC平台的《重生》系列，《新次元V2》以及《激次元》等等[strike] 实力为钱包减肥	[/strike][spoiler] 这么久了才来写评测真是对不住我花的钱哈（笑）	[/spoiler]
------------------------------------------------------------------------
[h1] 关于购买	[/h1]
现在steam已支持人民币结算，游戏价格比其他地区便宜了不少，《重生3》本体价格88元，遇上打折仅三四十元[spoiler] 15年感恩特惠期间《重生1》仅需17元	[/spoiler]，比PSV版及主机原版低了一大截，是玩家们完全可以承担的水平，需要注意的是，[b] 如果是在淘宝上购买，需分清PSV版和PC版甚至盗版	[/b]

[h1] 关于游戏性	[/h1]
既然是一款JRPG，那么可玩性自然就不低，曲折的剧情，出色的人设，堪称“恐怖”的声优阵容，要素收集等等每一项都能成为你继续玩下去的理由，但是相对应的，你需要一定的耐心，难免会出现“刷刷刷”的情况存在，但是，为了更好的游戏体验，何乐而不为呢？而且PC版支持手柄控制，不习惯键鼠的玩家可以用手柄当主机版玩，我个人也推荐手柄。
相信很多玩家进游戏第一件事就是切换至日语语音，其实英语语音也很不错，大家可以试一试不同的感觉。

[h1] 关于配置要求	[/h1]
《重生3》最低要求64位Win7，所以说还在用XP的玩家可以洗洗睡了，优化不是太好，配置较低的玩家可能会有卡顿现象。有玩家反映说有黑屏，死机，闪退的情况，但是我一次都没有遇到过（64位Win7+i7+980+16G），所以是不是优化或者盗版的锅，我无从得知。另外《重生3》最大分辨率为1920X1080，并不支持2K及以上的分辨率，本人使用的是4K屏，分辨率是游戏自动将1080P强行拉伸的，立绘倒是没多大问题，但是在地下城里，人物模型线条撕裂严重，特别是将视角拉远的情况下，锯齿很明显，倒也不至于影响正常游戏，但是视觉效果比较糟糕，算是《重生3》的一大遗憾。

[h1] 关于成就	[/h1]
PC版的成就与PSV版一样，下面简单介绍下：
Neptune, Start：开始游戏
Prologue Cleared-Chapter 9 Cleared：流程成就，每完成一章自动获得，注意第九章的成就需要进入GE和TE结局才可以获得，具体方法已有玩家在另外的评测里详细解释
Normal ending：达成普通结局
Good ending：达成好结局
True ending：达成真结局
Social Game Crusher：社交游戏毁灭者，真结局后的追加剧情里击败社交游戏双子
Violence, At Long Last：赢得第一场战斗
Hardcore：战斗100次
Battle Master：战斗500次
Combo Maker：第一次自定义普攻招式
Game Remake：完成一项计划书
Game Designer：完成200项计划书
You Are Now OP：单个回合里达成100000伤害
Combo Master：单个回合里达成100连击（hits）
My First Stella's ☆ Dungeon：第一次玩爬塔小游戏
Dungeon Master：爬塔小游戏里完成所有的楼层，20个区域共计10000层[spoiler] 慢慢爬吧少年	[/spoiler]
Aspiring Game Dev：制作一次光碟
Superstar Game Dev：制作出一次“神认定”的光碟
Level Cap, Get!：某个角色达到99级
Push It To The Limit：全员99级，[i] 不包括DLC人物	[/i]
Quest Master：完成100项任务
Rolling In Credits：累计获得1亿金钱
Loveable XXX：XXX与其他所有非DLC人物好感度上8
Super-dupermension Neptunia Master：这个都懂得，白金奖杯，完成所有成就

[h1] 关于语言	[/h1]
由于PC版为英文原版，UI全为英文注释，所以部分玩家看不懂，目前国内3DM及游侠均推出了汉化补丁，但是由于英文原版的对话翻译比较直白，且漏掉的对话字幕比较多，再加上汉化组的机翻，所以汉化效果可想而知，另外2ch上有人推出了日化补丁，有兴趣的玩家可以自行搜索下载。

[h1] 附录：Nep电视台有奖回答问题及答案	[/h1]
共27个问题，全部回答正确可获得一百万金钱奖励

20661720.review:
Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 3 is a colorful and fun JRPG filled with lots of cuteness,weirdness and an assortment of many cute animu girls. The odd,yet very interesting thing is that the girls are all based or represent game consoles or game engines.

Pros:
+Very fun story and dialogue between the characters
+ Cute and likeable characters
+4th wall breaking- Adds a certain charm to the game and makes things funnier
+Battling- You will be doing a lot of battles in which you will be doing the same thing over and over again,but because of the pretty animations and cool Special abilities,it doesn't get boring
+Design of characters- All of the characters have some things,like ribbons,hairpins or clothing that clues and hints on the game console or engine they are representing
+Customization- Many accesories and clothing to dress your characters into
+Do a lot of stuff- There is a lot of grinding to be done and for the most part it is well done
+Story is easy to get into- Playing the previous Hyperdimension games is not necessary to understand the story,since it pretty light-hearthed
+Light yuri and ship-teasing

Cons:
-Technical Difficulties- Had to mess a lot with the properties and install some other stuff to get the game to function properly. Sometimes the game stilll crashes for me on one of the two PC's I played this game on.
-Too much to grind- I said that the grinding was well done,but there are some things that require an insane amount of work and time spent to be achieved. Getting all of the endings is and maxing out lily ranks is super tedious.
-Dungeon and enemy recycling- This is a very big game,which uses recycled maps and enemies to a great amount. While I can tolerate the recycling of enemies,since a lot of RPG's and other games do that,I can't tolerate the recycling of the same map for 4+ times.
-Repetition of tropes- This is an anime-like game and expect to see a lot of stuff you saw a million times before (There is the topic of breast sizes,which the characters talk about quite a handful of times. It may be funny the first or second time,but after that it gets a bit ridiculous).
-Not enough yuri - Moar is required 

Overall,this game is/was very fun to play and I will spend more time playing it. Hyperdimension is one of the best RPG's I played and it will be a big favorite of mine. Looking forward to more Hyperdimension Neptunia games and I may play the other games aswell. Recommending this to everyone who likes RPG,anime stuff or just colorful and fun filled games.

20640715.review:
超次元海王星系列是以游戏业界为背景题材并将游戏主机平台和游戏产商拟人化的一个游戏，剧情内有着很多游戏业界的梗。
这个游戏系列的初心本意大概、也许、是——通过对游戏业界发展的拟人化剧情来向广大玩家普及游戏业界发展史尤其是家用游戏机发展史；是成为一个历史科普游戏系列。
不过，它其实就是个日呆萌豚游戏系列...........

游戏性：
一款萌豚向jrpg。
假如你是一个只想着快点砍掉BOSS脑袋，对日本动漫不感冒，也对里头的游戏业界历史梗完全没有兴趣的话，可能只会感到昏昏欲睡。
关于游戏性真的没啥好说的。。。不是日呆和系列信仰者，你会真的玩不下去。

剧情：
重生3的故事剧情发生在重生2的剧情之后。
在打败犯罪神之后，元气天真烂漫的neptunia难得地为自己的国家工作的时候，因为一次莫名其妙的意外去了另外一个游戏业界神次元，然后一次新的拯救游戏业界之旅就这么开始了。
神次元则是映射现实世界1980年代的游戏业界。

剧情流程很长很长，如果你是慢慢听着语音然后悠哉地玩下来，至少要100+小时。

角色：
3代完全继承了前代的角色们，加上新的故事角色，可用角色是最多的，豪华不要钱一样的cv表......声优豚不可错过
人物角色也是丰富多彩
其实我挺想用反派角色来着.......比如玲酱。

游戏系统：
3代总体上来说，除了一些小的系统变动（比如界面，挑战系统，新的迷宫地图）基本上和重生1、2代没有太大的差别。
最影响游戏过程的还是exe技能和驱动系统的变化，使用一次基本就把sp全部消耗完了。
当然，新的角色，新的剧情，已经足以让人不厌其烦地玩一款游戏3次（如果把重生1、2看成同款游戏）。这游戏，tm玩的就是信仰啊！

角色：
普鲁鲁特这个角色显然才是本作真正的主角，变身前后的两种都让人很喜欢！
在战斗中基本也是无可替代。

语言：
最大的问题依旧是老问题：语言问题。英文字幕感觉翻译的也不是很好，国内自然也没有好的汉化补丁，对于不会或不擅长日语的玩家（比如我）来说，即使连续3部玩下来，基本上也都听懂在说些什么了，还是注定有的梗和笑点难以很好理解。
懂日语的玩家还是去找一个日化补丁打上吧，原汁原味！

[spoiler]感谢挑战系统，让自己得到了一个合法正当地无限跳跃看panci，刷成残血无限听角色的残血状态弱气语音的理由！[/spoiler]

10/10.[spoiler]身为一个萌豚日呆海王星系列粉，无脑打10[/spoiler]

20638176.review:
[h1]Re;Birth 3 is all Re;Birth 2 is not.[/h1] 

If you're a Nepper, that's all you need to know to buy this game.

All the humor is back and all the actually fun characters are back, which makes this as good as Re;Birth 1, but bigger, longer, and with more fanservice (Tip: Buy the extra characters and extra content DLCs, they're really cheap and it's worth it, they all come with their own events per chapter, and you'll have a good laugh).

Character-wise, the Ultradimension CPUs are slightly different from their Hyperdimension counterparts, but I'm confident you'll enjoy the differences (for starters, UD Blanc actually has a personality, and the brief flashes of the love triangle with Plutia and Noire are pure gold), and Plutia is not only a most faithful embodiment of Sega's candid 8bit days (down to the consistent use of lilac and white color scheme), her CPU form is, well, an embodiment of Sega's abusive relationship with its customers on its last days; probably the best waifu-ification job of a gaming company of all the cast.

Gameplay-wise, it's fair I give you a heads-up: As you might have already noticed from Re;Birth 2 (if you had the misfortune of playing it), Neptunia has a habit of compulsive re-using: From dungeons to monsters to music tracks, every game asset from Re,Birth 1 is re-used time and time again. But then, the point of sale of Neptunia games lies with their charismatic characters and hilarious writing, so I didn't find myself bothered by the deja-vu and neither should you.

Speaking of Re;Birth 2, if you had the misfortune of playing it, you'll be glad Compile Heart took feedback to heart and castigated their prior game hilariously.

[b]Warning 2:[/b] Just as with Re;Birth 2, the last chapter and true ending require you to do some stuff. Fortunately, Re;Birth 3 is way more forgiving than 2 and the conditions are harder to miss. Just read a guide here on the forums and you're golden.

My only complain: If this game aimed for the early days of the console war... where are all the old discarded consoles?? Where's SNK? Where's Nec? Where's Panasonic? Where are Phillips and Bandai? Where's Mattel? That was one HUGE wasted opportunity. WARNING: COMMENT ON THE GAME's LAST CHAPTER [spoiler]I'd have actually left Planeptune in ruins after Ryghts' bombardment and turned Nep into a wandering Wuxia goof to remain faithful to what happened in the console wars. If they actually went into the part of cell phones in our current Second Videogame Crash, they could have gone all the way while they were at it.[/spoiler]

10/10, would Nep again (and probably will, New Game+ is an option). Can't wait for Hyperdevotion Noire and Action Unleashed to get to Steam.

20463984.review:
I've finally done it! I'm done drinking the kool-aid, stopped believing in false deities, and I've been Nep-Nep free for ... not even a year. Oh No... As much as I hate to admit it, Compile Heart's opus to moe console wars has succesfully stolen another 40+ hours of my time. Instead of playing Undertail or whatever it is the kiddies are going ga-ga for, I surrendered myself to the latest entry in the Neptunia Saga. 

Now why would I do such a silly thing?

By now, we're all familiar with how the Hyperdimension Neptunia formula works. These games are not known for their complex dungeons, intricate plots, or especially difficult battles. They're Sunday Funday affairs, the kind designed to make you feel like the good and awesome person that you are. You're smashing those wacky monsters by the thousands, crafting plans to unlock neat stuff, and enjoying a thorough introspective on the console industry and boob-jokes. That said, formulas eventually become stale. There's only so much that can be done with a concept. An injection of fresh ideas or even a change of direction is necessary to keep a game series interesting. 

How does Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth3 V Generation accomplish this daunting task? Um... It doesn't.

But it's like I always say: When the Devil isn't in my Crystal Light, he's in the details. Nep-Cubed stays fresh not by messing with the formula, but by improving on practically every aspect. First off, let's talk about the characters. In the last game, Nepgear is a nice girl, but she was saddled with the unfortunate task of playing an everyday heroine. The Neptunia series isn't built for characters like her. So, in N3p not only do we get Neptunia being her usual absurd self, she's joined by Plutia. With this gal, it's either sleepy-time or sadomasochistic time. Nepgear returns, but she's become a trifle touched in the head, possibly due to all of the complaints about how normal and boring she was. Noire also gets main-character duty this go-around. Her personality is: "It-It's not like I [i]want[/i] to play the straight-woman or anything!" Nearly everyone else makes an appearance in the story and/or the dozens upon dozens of optional cutscenes. Whereas Re;Birth 2 was lacking in personality, this game is practically a personality explosion. 

You know what else I disliked about Neptunia 2? Being stuck with the same party-members for the vast majority of the game. R3;Birth neps that issue in the bud. As soon as chapter 1, a deluge of playable characters are dropped in your proverbial lap. These heroines also receive a new ability called "awakening". It's basically an HDD-level boost for non-CPUs/Candidates. Share-shenanigans are a thing of the past as well. Once you reach the specific point in the story, you'll unlock a character, no colosseum or quest grinding necessary. 

The battle-system has received some slight revisions. The SP meter is tied into the CPU's ability to perform EXE moves. So if you perform so many special moves, or cast enough healing spells, you won't be able to perform EXEs, until you attack the enemy to rebuild the lost meter. There are also less EXE moves in general. While these changes can be considered nerfs, this attempt at balance makes the fights a little more complicated than: spam rush combos > spam EXEs > spam level-up screens. Still, unless you're actively trying to stay weak, you'll shred 90% of the enemies in this game.

Another practically life-changing improvement is the "search" function. When you can't be arsed to remember where a "magical contract" or a "magical contact" can be found, you can run an in-game search. Yes, shift+tab and the nearest FAQ in the Steam community is available, but at least it's obvious that Compile Heart cares. Stella (ugh) also makes her return. She's got a nice racket going doesn't she? Everytime she makes an appearance in a Neptunia game, the urge to buy DLC rises by 5,000,000%. This time around she's exploring a massive tower. A number of extremely useful plans are tied to this tamogotchi nightmare, so you might as well fork over that extra dollar. At least it doesn't take her 12+ hours to explore the later locations.

But you know what? One of the best qualities of R3;Birth is those times where it shows some charm. I mean, okay there's still plenty of fan-service, the plot and villains being ridiculous, and the overabundance of cute girls doing kyuuuute thangs. Somewhere underneath all of that nonsense, there are rare moments that warm the ancient & cavernous ruins I consider to be my heart. I'd be perfectly content if this series was just a farce, but it understands the right ways to capture my attention. Then again, for all I know this is just another method Nep-fever sinks it's claws into my soul. Idea Factory is making sure I stick around to buy Neptunia VII, and the musou-like hack & slash, and the Noire SRPG, and Blanc Vs Zombies, and the Sega Hard Girls cross-over...

It's questionable how long I'll be able to participate in this rodeo. The Re;Birth series always does enough to keep the players addicted, and this entry is a continuation of everything that works. If you're expecting something more, then I don't know what to tell you. You certainly can't expect to enjoy this game if the previous entries didn't grab you. However, if you're a fan, then I'm positive that this entry won't disappoint.

20438211.review:
Its combat system is turnbased and kindof a mix between Xenosaga and Tales games. Without the depth. Each character has a max of about 3 special abilities/spells. Also the characters are not balanced with each other at all, there are some characters that are clearly much more powerful than their counterparts, so really there is no reason to ever use them. The combat system is pretty important, because you will be doing a lot of fighting. And I do mean a lot, its pretty much grinding simulator, the game.

As for the comedy elements, its... well its just really not that funny. The game is self aware, but it just doesn't execute it all that well. The puns and the references are kindof fun for an hour, but after that it just gets repetitive. Here is an example of one of their recurring 'jokes', Neptunia/toher says I want to play video games, someone gets mad and yells at them, they are scared of person and call them a stupid name that signifies they are angry/unreasonable. Did you laugh? Well that is repeated about 59 times so you had better enjoy it.

Another thing is the side characters that you get while going through the game. What is the point of them? They aren't even acknowledged in the main game. It is entirely possible for you to have a character, that according to the story is in the castle doing important work, also somehow go around helping you destroy monsters to fulfill your daily quota. Some characters dont have any story at all, and seem to be shoved in just so they could have more characters.

Also it is very hard to play with a keyboard, this game was made for a controller and shows it, so if you dont have a controller, you will have a bad time figuring out the controls.

Overall the game wasn't terrible, it just wasn't that good.

20335261.review:
Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth3: V Generation is a remake of a 2012 RPG game released on the PS3, and a sequel to the second Re;Birth game. Originally on PS Vita game, it was later ported to the PC and released on Steam.

Just like with the previous two games, it's a unique take on the idea of "Console Wars" with every console being anthropomorphised into a "Goddess". Being a direct sequel to Re;Birth2, it takes place a few years after defeating the Deity of Sin once and for all. Everything returned to normal, and peace ruled over the world, but something bad is happening again and confused Neptune is thrust into a completely different dimension set in the past / alternate reality where she'll meet the predeccessor who founded Planeptune, Plutia, as well as different versions of the characters from her home world, and will have to figure out who's behind her dimension traveling, as well as stand against the local threat - the Seven Sages, opposing the Goddesses and their newly-found nations.

The gameplay is basically your typical turn-based jRPG with minor tactical elements. Your characters and enemies take turns performing attacks, using abilities or items. It's rather simple to get a grasp if you played any other turn-based RPG. Outside of dungeon exploring and fighting, you can use shops, view the gallery, accept and complete quests, or use special "Plans" to add or modify existing content in the game. The difficulty feels just right - it's not as hard as old-school jRPGs, but also not easy enough that you will be bored (unless you specifically overlevel your characters for the upcoming fights). The game even hands you certain Plans that make the enemies tougher or easier, so there's always some way of tuning the difficulty a bit if you want a challenge or - the opposite - want to focus on the story. Majority of the content is grind-based, however, so if you care about exploring everything, you'll have to level up your characters quite a lot. That being said, the general progression has been improved upon in comparison to the first two Re;Birth games - you don't have to grind nearly as much to get past certain boss fights. Also, there is an actual post-game now, and even some bonus storylines and events if you get the True Ending.

Another thing to mention is that while the previous Re;Birth games on Steam had some minor performance issues and crashes, this one runs very smoothly, and never crashed once for me. It shows that Idea Factory knows how to make a solid PC port.

The story is quite engaging, with you traveling across the alternate Gamindustri, making friends with the alternate versions of past characters and fighting against the common threat, interspersed with jokes about gaming cliches, breaking the fourth wall, and all sorts of humor. Of course, it's full of fanservice in one way or another, but what would you expect from a game that creates Moe Anthropomorphisms of game consoles?

The graphics are good. You might notice blurred textures here and there, but it's nothing big, and it's pretty to look at, especially that the general quality was noticeably improved in comparison to the past games. The only reason you might not like it is if you don't like anime style.

In the sound department, we get mostly electronic music or rock, with quite a lot memorable or downright awesome themes. It's definitely worth listening to even outside the game. An interesting thing to note is that Nobuo Uematsu, the composer for [i]Final Fantasy[/i], worked on some of the tracks in the game.

As far as the DLC goes... there is only one. Well, technically more, but Idea Factory performed an awesome move and decided to include [i]all[/i] the DLC characters [i]and[/i] Additional Content Packs, so by purchasing the game you automatically have access to 15+ bonus party members and level cap 999, as well as all the extra Colliseum fights and dungeons. The only one that doesn't come with the game helps you level up faster and makes the optional Stella's Dungeon minigame a lot easier and faster, neither of which feel neccessary.

The game also pretty much requires New Game+ in order to unlock everything, since one playthrough does not yield enough MB (Megami Bytes) to craft every Plan you can get.

Overall, this is a great game, featuring adorable, likeable characters, nice graphics, great music, interesting storyline, as well as lots of humor and content. I heavily recommend it to anyone who likes jRPGs that don't take themselves too seriously or cutesy games.

20311069.review:
Half JRPG, half Visual Novel; Neptune and our favorite characters of all shapes and sizes return for another game full of light humor, fanservice, fourth wall breaking and button mash-to-win. Compared to the previous titles, the battle system has been revamped, changing the SP/EXE drive system, introducing plans to extend combos, enabling up to four characters to fight simultaneously and more. Plus you no longer have to mash the Y key in dungeons while hearing the same sound over and over to find hidden goods. They're now in convenient boxes scattered across the world. Yay!

Story-wise, the game sticks to its roots. Everything is taken lightly, cuteness and the occasional fanservice is everywhere. Some jokes are taken a tad too far - the size of Blanc's chest to fourth wall breaking stacked onto fourth wall breaking. It's actually a rather refreshing Visual Novel, with a good portion of the story events voiced. Plus, the option to swap between the English and Japanese voices is a plus.

In terms of the combat and dungeoning, Re;birth3 does a better job at balance and dungeon progression, with a defined difficulty curve in the story dungeons and a large number of side dungeons in case one wishes to do some grinding. Yes, the dungeons are repetitive, often the same tileset with minor modifications, and most enemies (there are actually many different types) usually share the same sprites, but it isn't too big of a deal. The new combat system starts feeling a bit odd, considering SP and EXE are now one and the same, but eventually you get used to it and realize how ridiculous SP Boosters are. Unfortunately this makes Rush type skills far less valuable as SP Boosters now contribute directly to EXE Drive and Skills can be spammed less. The plus side is you don't have to grind EXE every single time a dungeon instance is entered or reset.

Like the other remakes, re;birth3 has a ton of DLC (which is actually included this time for free! sans the mega-convenient one) adding in a ton of humorous events and characters. Stella's dungeon is back from re;birth2 with far more valuable rewards to be gained. Mostly the same system, but some bonus items can be scored by having a scout detect a new area upon clearing a floor.

Overall, as a JRPG, the game is quite simplistic, and fairly grindy (even with Super EXP Up). Not really for everyone, especially those who aren't really a fan of the art/story/characters. As a Visual Novel, the game is incredibly entertaining, making events shy away from mashing a button hoping it ends to something worth savoring. Especially if it's voiced. If you're a fan of the Neptunia games, this is definitely worth it. If you don't mind grindy JRPGs and a bit of fanservice, this is definitely worth it. Eh. As long as you don't mind the art style, characters, JRPG elements and writing, this game is totally worth it.
