20122152.review:
[h1]Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth3 V Generation[/h1]

[b]Introducción:[/b]
Quien compra este tipo de juegos de IF y CompileHeart, sabe lo que se va a encontrar, juegos de corte visual anime, vistoso, colorido y divertido, sin prestar mucha atención a la historia, que siempre tiene connotaciones divertidas, gags, provocativas y algo absurdas (aunque hay excepciones claro).

[b]Historia:[/b]
La historia tiene un trasfondo relativamente real, ya que posiciona a las consolas de diversas generaciones (tomando principalmente el rol de las más modernas), como personajes, y las introduce en lo que fue la guerra de consolas, relatando [b][u]a su manera[/u][/b] los sucesos de estas "guerras", incluyendo no solo los sistemas principales, si no otros, además de varias franquicias y compañías, que en cierto modo colaboran en el juego.
La tónica general es muy humorística, con algunos pequeños giros y escaramuzas, que te sacan una sonrisa en más de una ocasión.

[b]Sistema de juego:[/b]
El sistema es de un uso bastante sencillo, aunque para primerizos y si no has jugado a los anteriores, es preferible seguir los mini-tutoriales in-game, es de los que más me gusta, ya que es semi-activo-táctico y resulta muy entretenido, sobretodo a la hora de encajar el mayor número de combos, o rompe-defensas.

[b]Gráficos:[/b]
En esta versión de PC, están bastante optimizados, y aunque no van muy allá, se ve estupendamente, solo se puede achacar unas cuantas cosas, la optimización a 60fps no es demasiado buena, bajando bastante al entrar a una mazmorra y pre-cargar los monstruos en el plano, no siendo este su único fallo, ya que también el sonido tiende a fallar en algunos momentos de la exploración de mazmorras, particularmente en las que tienen lugar eventos con personajes, dejando sin sonido los pasos, saltos, menús y otros efectos SFX (básicamente casi cualquier sonido, excepto la música de escenario).

[b]Sonido:[/b]
Ya he comentado los fallos de sonido, que creo que tienen que ver con la mala optimización de los 60fps, así que solo me queda enumerar que algunos temas son bastante buenos y otros simplemente imperceptibles, en general esta bastante bien, pero posiblemente es algo que se podría mejorar.
Además tiene otro pequeño fallo en las voces y es que cuando se juntan 2 o más personajes, ya sea gritando o hablando al mismo tiempo (generalmente gritando), aumentan los decibelios momentáneamente, rompiendo la armonía sonora del juego, no es excesivamente molesto, pero sinceramente, tampoco gusta.

[b]Jugabilidad:[/b]
El juego es muy sencillo de jugar, uno se hace rápido al control, no tiene demasiadas "pausas" y la historia avanza a un ritmo muy bueno, no haciéndose pesado en ningún momento, la verdad es que es un punto a favor, además la cantidad de personajes jugables, trajes y otros accesorios, lo hacen muy dinámico.

[b]Conclusión:[/b]
En general el juego es divertido, no es especialmente adictivo, pero tampoco te desanima, es de esos juegos que gusta jugar en ratitos. Contiene bastantes gags relacionados con videojuegos conocidos y otros no tan conocidos, un poco de fanservice que nunca viene mal (siempre que no sea excedente) y un humor particularmente absurdo que siempre te saca una sonrisa, si estas especialmente ligado al mundo de los videojuegos y al anime (si el anime no es lo tuyo, entonces este juego seguramente no sea adecuado para ti).

[b]Mi valoración personal:[/b]
-Historia 5/10
-Gráficos 7/10
-Sonido/Música 7/10
-Jugabilidad 8.5/10
-Diversión 7/10
-Global: 7.5/10

19754491.review:
I'll use this review to compare it to the previous entries since if you're looking at the third game in the series, then you probably already know what you're getting into.

Story: Whereas Rebirth 1 and Rebirth 2 had almost no continuity, Rebirth 3 actually directly follows Rebirth 2 in terms of story, so it may be a good idea to play that (though honestly you won't miss out on much of the story if you haven't played the second game).

Gameplay: Like Rebirth 2, you can have four characters in the front lines during battle. New changes include the removal of the EXE drive (SP is used instead and is generated similarly; SP potions are pretty much gone). EX Finishers are now selected one per category, which makes it easier to tell what they do and makes combat planning a lot easier. Beyond that it's more of the same.

The port is decent too, being stable everywhere aside from a couple areas. No FPS cap, though higher framerates tend to screw with the jump function sometimes (not a big deal).

A decent,but predictable plot.Very deep, thought provoking Sub-"plots" however.The real draw to the game are the characters,which vary in personality as well as being plentiful.Though some are very shallow, others less so,the comedy that ensues from them,and whatever other reason this game appeals to you *wink*,is worth the strife of plot conveniences being used on the regular.

Gameplay is a cross between action and turn-based, with slight exploration elements to find hidden treasures and improved dungeon complexity over the previous two installments. It's standard Compile Hearts fare to improve slightly over time, so this game is technically superior over the previous two available on steam. 

Sound is heavily rehashed.This may be a good thing or a bad thing,depending on how you like it before.

Graphics are Japanese standard, with a focus on aesthetics rather than technical flair. That aside the graphics are par for the course of a low budget title ported from a handheld console.

Overall pretty dope.
More Neppu so I'm happy.

19542224.review:
59/100 (ok)

TLDR
I enjoyed it, after it lowered my expectations.

OVERVIEW
The game can be summarized a mediocre/budget JRPG (with heavily re-used assets and monotonous gameplay) 48% of the time, and the remaining 48% being listening to character interactions 50% of which (so 24% of total) is actually voice acted by the actors, with the remaining 4%  being miscellaneous (like making your character jump while your camera is trying to look up her skirt). It was an overall peaceful and somewhat dull experience, but I did like the relatively calm story which was unprecedented/unusual, & some of the choreography of the animations as well as some of the gimmicks (though I thought the animations were bad), I felt the combat system was deeper than all other other JRPG I played (eternal sonata, quest 64) which is something I enjoyed.

After playing through the entire game, and getting all of the steam achievements (didn't do new game+) I finally feel qualified to make this review.


PLAYSTYLE/PERSPECTIVE
From the perspective of an western gamer, who can only speak/read english.
I played as a semi-completionist, searching through most of the dungeons as they became available, cataloging the monsters and loot drops, but not fretting too much over missed content (locked behind RNG) too much.
I played as a binge player, who would commit entire days to this game.
I actively avoided the free beneficial DLC content (I dislike most/all? DLC on principle) perhaps so I can experience the game as "it was intended" for the average (non steam) buyer.
I came in expecting something of the quality of dota 2, tribes 2, fallout 3, deadcore, perimeter, stalker, delta force 2, halo, the total war series, serious sam, eternal sonata, ETC. Generally things that are AA or AAA quality (sometimes A).

BEGINNING
It was an awful first impression, after even downloading the game I met technical difficulty, where I did not have the required download installed for the game, I came in expecting to be submerged into a pleasant fantasy land of anime girls in a gamey world immediately and conveniently, too bad I had to have my experience halted by this rather rude intrusion of "reality" (the technical problematic lens). Once I got the game to work (by downloading a somewhat vaguely described redistributable on my internet browser), and being relieved, I was met with what I thought was a shockingly bad introduction, where upon my character gets beaten down, but what was bad about it was that the animation quality was surprisingly bad (like a good quality MMD fan animation) and that my character made only 1 pain-scream when being struck, giving the impression of a bad Wii game (might sound small, but it was huge to me). Usually games like this want to leave a good impression, but this one left an awful one, heck, even the game "chex quest" somehow left a better first impression than this game (and that game literally came out of my cereal box). I was planning to get this game refunded during this disappointing phase, but knowing I had 2 hours to "demo" the game before steam refunds were disabled, I continued until I got a better look at the game. In a way, it is quite shocking that a game like this would leave such a bad impression so quickly, as if they aren't aware that there is a refund policy in place.

BEGINNING 2
In a bit of a haze, I proceeded in the game, expecting further disappointments, which showed rather quickly when I found my first segment of storytelling that lacked voice acting, me coming from games like fallout 3, skyrim, and eternal sonata expected that all or most of the lines displayed in the chat box would be uttered by some voice actor, but rather, only about 50% of the main story is voiced, and only about 20% of sidequests (if any) were voiced, I was again further negatively surprised, but this defect was somewhat beneficial/mitigated; as the lack of the voice acting let me fill in the voice acting with my imagination (such as replacing some voices with voices from other games, usually inappropriately), and in a way this somewhat added to my experience. Though, I doubt others would rise to this "challenge", and is still a fault to be considered, I really would have preferred a 60-70% voice acting on the story dialog, but sadly, it was not the case.
There were 2 notable flaws in the game that left somewhat lasting impression which is the dominatrix's lost 3 second static pose when she "transforms into existence" with bad english lip-syncing, and a camera that clips through her segmented sword, and the playstation character's sometimes cringe-worthy "tryhard" deep voice, though I was fond of some of the defects (tryhard voice).






MIDDLE/LATE
The middle of the game was perhaps the best enjoyed part of it, after I had my expectations passively beaten down my the overall quality, and this was a time of discovery. I really started to get into the more difficult content, and I started to notice some of the complexities of the combat system, like how one might want to align turns to initiate a guard break, and use ultimates, and typically having enough complexity to cause me to delay and think what action to do sometimes, and with enough complexity to prevent it from getting too formulaic too quickly, (though formulas are naturally developed) in fact, this would be the most tactically deep JRPG I have played, and I enjoyed it, though the system tends to degrade later on and problems started to crop up (formulas were developed), since I was playing as a semi-completionist, I would do dungeons, but most of the dungeons would only have 1 formulaic way of "clearing them"; 1. beat each enemy until it dropped all of it's items, 2, fight the boss 1-3 times, which typically require 1 of 3 strategies with some permutations (1. power attack spam/use ultimates, for the weakest bosses, 2. Buff your characters, break guard/weaken enemies, then kill with ultimate, 3. buff, weaken guard, buff, align turns (making it so that most of your characters will be able to attack before the bosses turn), use ultimates, then finish off.), 3. Run through the dungeon again, ignoring the enemies, and headbutting the camouflaged boxes so that you can better "catalog" the items that come out of them (because it tends to be random). Then rinse/repeat for every other dungeon you unlock, skipping step 1 for upgraded dungeons that recycle enemies. In a way, step 3 was relaxing, (after I got the upgrade that trivializes finding the boxes but hellish before) so it wasn't that bad. But the boss fight distinctly lacked variety in methodologies to beat, there were some helpful differences such as the 7 elite boss type, and the boss with disabling helpers, but much too rare to be really helpful (about 4% are different), which is surprising, I'd think that more exotic bosses would be easy to implement. There is also a minor concern of stats, there is no explanation of them, while some stats can largely be figured out (like strength being attack power) some can be mistaken for others, one could think that vitality is related to HP amount instead of it functioning as "armor" or "men" (mental?) having some affect on SP(mana) regeneration instead of it being "magic armor", this is largely irrelevant since you cannot really "build" characters to have extreme stat imbalances and/or character specialties, and how the game is generally very easy, (even going so far as to send some story bosses in waves, instead all at once even though it is explicit that the bosses are in a group) thus not really requiring understanding of the stats, but another rather small deficiency.

Due to the character limit, you will need to search the last 3 pages of the comments to find the remainder of the review.

19538674.review:
Re;Birth 3, just another great game in the Neptunia series. Outranks the two before in many ways but for me it lacks the thing the 2 first had. The Difference of really being a remake. Yeah, it is a Neptunia Victory to those who havent played Victory before and it completes the original trilogy for the computer. But the 2 before this were so amazingly different than the originals that they impressed me. This game is also absolutely brilliant, dont get me wrong. I love the plan systems in the Re;Births. But the point is it isnt as much as a remake as the two first ones. Ofc it has alot of differences to the actual game it was made of. The Combo system, Awakening, Stellas Dungeon, and ofc the brilliant plan system. In this version they have repaired the things that the original lacked. As a whole, it is just perfect as it is. Its fun to play, has great music, great story, amazing new characters, FREE DLCS!! and it just is very complete.

Pros 
+ Improved remake system
+ Most DLCs are free
+ Great story
+ Amazing characters
+ Makes you laugh
+ Is very cute
+ Reasonably low PC requirements
+ Stellas Dungeon improvements
+ Lot of gameplay and content

Mixed 
+/- Can be quite easy

For me it has no cons, its just so complete.

终于打出一个结局了，感觉这一部剧情好长啊，打出一次结局的时间都够重生2四周目的时间了，当然对话内容太多拉长了游戏的时间，而且我喜欢把级别刷高，花了一点时间......

但是内容倒是挺详细而且还很有趣，把一大票人物都做了对话什么的以便玩家对其更多了解（或者让玩家看更多的福利），感觉酱油味儿比以前淡了不少，这一部的组队阵容甚是强大，简直是全明星阵容......
剧情上有几处和动画都挂上钩了[spoiler]但是IF酱被塞茄子那里为什么没有配图啊？！有那么几处该配福利的地方都没有图，Steam卖的是不是和谐版啊？！（大雾）[/spoiler]，依旧是游戏界大佬百合拯救世界,[spoiler]大部分反派强行洗白[/spoiler]没啥说的......游戏界面做了些许改动，比以前好看多了......
Stella小游戏变得更方便，随时可以进行（重生2貌似是要退出迷宫去四个国家才能进行），让Stella帮忙刷素材节约时间......
但是现在SP条要靠自己打怪刷了（退出迷宫重进也白搭），而且放EXE要耗费SP值我觉得不大适应，觉得用起来不大方便（因为感觉SP条不如原来的EXE条好刷啊）......
感觉解锁迷宫变得容易了......
多了一个Nep电视直播功能，可以回顾回顾剧情，电视购物，还能有奖问答哦！全部9章的27个问题答对了奖励100w哦！
怪物大部分还是老伙计，地图有几张新的......
游戏玩儿着感觉比重生2要好，重生2在这三部里出错退出次数最多（2、3次吧大概）......

当然，也有一点点点不满意的地方：
个别对话还是没声音......
人物模型可以更精细一些嘛......觉得三部下来没啥长进......嘛......其实无所谓啦......
对话的内容啊，全篇一直在讨论球，你说要是一群绅士讨论球讨论个不停还好说，你们一群妹纸天天对话内容三句不离球......偶尔看着有点无聊呢......可以聊点别的嘛是不是啊（比如说腿）......


嘛，总之这种游戏但凡买来能玩儿的一般都会给好评吧，感觉挺有意思的嘛，虽然我不爱看大段对话（感觉这一部对话尤其欢乐，估计是人物比较多的原因），可是里面的妹纸还是很萌的嘛，可以满足不同口味的绅士（幼女控，萝莉控，少女控，御姐控，抖S，抖M，巨乳控，贫乳控，变态控，[spoiler]中年处女控，老年处女控，兽控[/spoiler]，等等等等等等等）
最后，小Histoire简直太萌啦！\(^o^)/

19485000.review:
Больше текста богу текста... просто дофига текста, сюжет же держится на уровне предыдущих частей. И это, надо заметить, далеко не комплимент. Быстро пробегая все данжи (имея хай лвл перса и сражаясь только с босами, убивая их с пары ударов) для открытия лучшей концовки (читал что от исследованных данжей зависит открытие финальных 6 нужных) и скипая кучу текста вы потратите 15 часов. При этом ничего координально нового не увидите по сравнению с предыдушими частями: такая же графика, такие же картинки, такой же сюжет и персонажи... уныло. Как и остальные части рекомедовал бы брать только на распродаже, иначе своих денег явно не стоят. Это "типичная японская игра", отнють не в хорошем понимании этого выражения, или лучше сказать "типичный порт типичной японской игры". Потому не рекомендую.
П.С. Единственное что действительно понравилось в этих играх - система комбо, потому и играл в них до конца. Разумеется взяв их на распродаже.
П.П.С. Ранее не рекомендовал эту игру брать без скидки, но... все познается в сравнении. Посмотрел на DRAGON QUEST HEROES и Tales of Zestiria, которые вроде как являются японскими ролевыми играми (jRPG) и на их цену. После 5 минут игры в одну и во вторую понял что Нептуния очень хорошая игра как для JRPG и персонажи там не такие уж и плохие, хоть и шаблонные и однотипные данжи - не самое плохое, на что можно жаловаться. К тому же даже без скидки стоит дешевле. Посему меняю своб оценку - брать можно. Всяко лучше того треша вышло.

19452253.review:
Najlepsza gra z serii wydana dotąd na Steam. Serio, nie wiem do czego mógłbym się przyczepić. 

Tradycyjnie zacznę od fabuły, która moim zdaniem, jest o poziom wyżej od poprzednich odsłon serii. Nie jest to oczywiście poziom Wiedźmina, ale nie tego oczekuje się po grze tego typu. W przeciwieństwie do Re;Birth 2, gra jest sequelem poprzedniej części, bohaterki pamiętają wydarzenia z poprzedniczki, jednak nie ma to praktycznie żadnego znaczenia. Re;Birth 3 to oddzielna historia, dziejąca się w zupełnie innym wymiarze, do którego trafia Neptune, która na całe szczęście powraca jako główna bohaterka. Razem z Neptune powraca także humor, za który polubiłem serię w Re;Birth 1, i za którego brak w dwójce miałem sceptyczne nastawienie do tej części. Jak już wspomniałem, historia toczy się w innym niż w poprzedniczce świecie, który mocno czerpie z przełomu piątej, szóstej i częściowo siódmej generacji konsol.

Kolejną rzeczą, która rzuciła mi się w oczy podczas rozgrywki, to dungeony, które co prawda powtarzają się, ale szczerze mówiąc nie doświadczyłem jakiejś mocnej monotonii w żadnym punkcie gry. Podobnie ma się sprawa z bossami. 
Poprawiono także sam przebieg rozgrywki. W żadnym punkcie gry nie zostałem zatrzymany przez niepokonaną barierę grindu. W niektórych momentach co prawda miałem trochę problemów z bossami, jednak nie był to problem braku dostatecznie wysokiego levela.

Poprawiono także mniej znaczące rzeczy takie jak  plan na koloseum, który dostajemy dosyć szybko i w przeciwieństwie do Re;Birth 2 mamy do niego dostęp kiedy tylko chcemy. Drugą pozytywną zmianą jest przeniesienie Stella's Dungeon z poziomu miasta do menu, co oznacza, że możemy wysyłać ją nawet wtedy, kiedy znajdujemy się w podziemiu.

Co do samego Stella's Dungeon, został BARDZO poprawiony. Zasady są podobne co w Re;Birth 2, jednak sama minigierka stała się bardzo user friendly. Zdołalem przejść wszystkie poziomy bez kupowania DLC bez większych problemów. Stella nie umiera już 10 razy pod rząd z jakiegoś głupiego powodu, a przedmioty które dostajemy po jej powrocie są dosyć przydatne. Warto wspomnieć także o innym, fajnym ulepszeniu: teraz zamiast Felisa możemy wybierać spośród dużej liczby postaci, głównie tych występujących na mapie w postaci chirper eventów.

Same chirper eventy zostały w końcu zrobione jak należy; Na mapie pojawiają się tylko te, które zawierają plany dungeonów i zmian do nich. Reszta znajduje się w miastach.

Ostatnią zmianą w rozgrywce, moim zdaniem jedną z najważniejszych jest wyszukiwarka. W KOŃCU. Teraz, zamiast szukania danego itemu po internecie wystarczy wcisnąć odpowiedni przycisk i pokażą się miejsca i przeciwnicy dropiący dany item.

Optymalizację porównałbym do Re;Birth 1 - nie jest tak źle, jak w dwójce, ale nie jest idealnie. W ciągu 40 godzin, gra wywaliła się raz, co nie jest złym wynikiem.

Teraz powinienem przejść do minusów, jednak prawde mówiąc nie mam pojęcia co tu wpisać. Na odczepnego mógłbym się przyczepić do uproszczenia EXE drive i przeniesienia go do SP.

Podsumowując: Najlepsza Neptunia jaka do tej pory pojawiła się na steamie.

Plusy:
[list]
    [*]Wyszukiwarka itemów
    [*]Ulepszony względem poprzedniczek gameplay
    [*]Plutia
    [*]Posortowane Chirper eventy
    [*]User friendly Stella's Dungeon
    [*]Powrócił humor i notoryczne łamanie czwartej ściany z Re;Birth 1
    [*]Różnorodne dungeony
    [*]Fabuła poziom wyżej od poprzedniczek
[/list]

Neutralne:
[list]
    [*]Niektóre z przydatnych przedmiotów dostępne tylko w Stella's Dungeon
    [*]dla niektórych - stylistyka
[/list]

Minuty:
[list]
    [*]Na odczepnego: uproszczenie EXE drive
[/list]

Plays like the previous Neptunia games in the series.

[h1]New Features[/h1]
- Challenge system: gain +stats, additional combo slots, for doing mundane things in game. It will make a completionist cry.
- New dungeon mode: Big Dungeon Mode. 
- Stella's Minigame overhauled. Now is more relevant to the main game with being a bigger source of drops and required to get more dungeons and modes unlocked.
- in-game Nepedia makes it easier to find who drops what and where for those unlockables. Best update IMO.

[h1]Dissapointments[/h1]
- Godly/Sucky game discs are still the same from Re;birth 1. Would like to see new Godly games added as the series progresses.
- In-game outfits and CPU mods seem to have been moved to the store rather than made as random drops. Kiss your life goodbye just grinding for the cash now.

19368540.review:
¡NEPU! Neptunia vuela de nuevo igual que en la primera entrega, esta vez por culpa de un agujero que la manda a otra dimensión. La cual es casi clavadita a gamiindustri pero... oh! ¡Ahora no es una diosa y... ¡¡¡Está envejeciendo!!!!
Advertencia: El juego tiene bugs criticos (leer más abajo)

[b]COSAS BUENAS[/b]
La Gran mayoría las misma que las del uno y dos (analisis aqui)
[list]
[*][b]Cómico[/b]: Aunque a un nivel algo menor que el 1º Es lo más llamativo y divertido del juego, las situaciones y los dialógos dan para muchas coñas
[*][b]Nuevos personajes jugables[/b]: A todos los que ya había en el 1 y 2 esta vez le sumamos plutia, peashy, ef, compa, falcom e historie (no, no me he equivocado ya lo veréis :p), ¡mi adorada peashy rompebarriguitas! :3
[*][b]Estética[/b]: de anime/manga aunque sencilla, es agradable y bonita, además se les pueden ver las bragas (¡Eh, espera! ¿Esto era lo suficientemente importante como para mencionarlo?).
[*][b]Videos[/b]: algunas parte de las historias son vídeos.
[*][b]Animaciones[/b]: De lo más llamativo del juego. durante la parte de dialogos veremos a nuestros personajes moverse (con limitaciones) hacer gestos, etc. Y durante el combate (ver abajo)
[*][b]Combate[/b]: Con animaciones muy llamativas al usar ataques SP o EXE, con un sistema peculiar a la hora de planear tus ofensivas, sobre todo combinado con los chips de mejora. Además ahora con los neuvos personajes las opciones se multiplican
[*][b]Historia y villanos[/b]: En esta entrega están más "cuidados".
[*][b]Stella dungeon[/b]: AHORA SÍ ESTÁ COMPLETO ESTE MINIJUEGO, que nos llena de materiales.
[*][b]Guiños y coñas[/b]: El juego entero es una parodia de videojuegos/compañias/personajes/animes , empezando por la exclamación de solid snake (!) 
[*][b]Personalización[/b]: Tanto del estilo de combate que queramos llevar a traves de los ataques, builds a la estetica y equipo que llevan nuestors personajes, nota, eso sí, que algunos vestidos y complementos son muy cros porque están pensados para que te los hagas en las fases finales del juego.
[*][b]Doblaje[/b]:Puedes jugarlo con las voces en japo o inglés, como prefieras, y además es un "full voice" excepto alguna parte de los DLC's.
[*][b]Compatibilidad completo mando Xbox[/b]: de forma nativa que hace el juego sea muy sencillo de manejar e intuitivo
[*][b]Coliseo[/b]: si te ha gustado mucho el juego, podrás jugarlo bastante más tras pasartelo gracias a las batallas del coliseo que llegan hasta el lvl 999.
[*][b]¡Nepu![/b]: Tienes a nepu nepu (aunque no de inicio, ya que está prisionera D:)
[*][b]Más variedad de enemigos[/b]: Por fin una cosa que se echaba mucho de menos en las dos entregas anteriores.
[/list]

[b] COSAS MALAS[/b]
[list]
[*][b]Idioma[/b]: sólo disponible en inglés (audio, textos) y japo (audio), el nivel de inglés usado en el juego es medio.
[*][b]Sistema lioso para conseguir algunos drops[/b]: En este caso el problema es que han variado algunso drops respeto a la versión consolas, pero bueno, con cualquier guia no te será problema.
[*][b]Port[/b]: CUTREPORT que da como consecuencia:
[*][b]Bugs[/b]: El juego tiene varios bugs críticos que impiden en varias partes avanzar lo cual es una putada (a dia 21/11/2015) además de la inestabilidad que hace aveces pete, ambos errores se corrigen parcheando el ejecutable si tienes un SO de 64bits, pero si lo tienes de 32... ¡CUIDADO! 
[*][b]FPS y rendimiento[/b]: Tira mucho de pc, ¡demasiado! Y además hay caidas constantes de FPS ¡lo cual tiene delito!
[/list]
[b] COSAS MEH~ o llamativas[/b]
[list]
[*][b]Música[/b]: ¡Más música! Auqnue sigue sin ser una maravilla.
[*][b]Mucho diálogo[/b]: Si no te gusta leer...
[/list]

Las mécanicas del juego están más pulidas, la mazmorra de estela por fin está completa, hay más variedad de enemigos, mejor historia, es decir ¡AVANZA! Seria muy bueno de no ser por esos bugs criticos que hacen pete el juego, si tenéis un SO de 64bits no pasa nada, se parchea y solo tendréis caidas de FPS, pero en caso contrario, ¡CUIDADO!

Anexo:
[b]DLCs[/b]
¿Vas a pillarte el Histy's Emergency Aid Plan Pack?
En este caos este único DLC es el seguro de steall y un superboost de experiencia, así que ya te adelanto que no merece la pena, ya que ahora la mazmorra de estella se puede pasar perfectamente sin DLC y si vas subiendo de lvl muyy rápidamente pierdes el equilibrio del juego (excepto si vas a por el lvl 999)

Espero os haya servido y... ¡A SEGUIR NEPUNEANDO!

19344520.review:
What would you expect in this game?

[b]It's Neps! What else would you expect? Oh and let's not forget about Plutia/Iris Heart, oh God.[/b]


[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
Nepu. (Nep's way of saying yes)

Nep-Nep/10












[h1]Okay okay, I'll be serious this time.[/h1]

Seriously though, it's a fun RPG as I enjoyed Re;Birth 3 the most out of all the Neptunia games, so I definitely recommend this.

[h1]Story![/h1]
[u][b]Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 3 V Generation[/b][/u] takes place a couple of years after the events of Re;Birth 2 and so, I won't spoil much of the story, but to summarize, Neptune all of a sudden gets transported to another dimension, landing in another Gamindustri very similar to the other Gamindustri that she knows. Along the way, she meets some new friends and very familiar faces along the way and maybe some new foes. Will she be able to return back to her home in the Hyperdimension? Or will she forever be stuck in the Ultradimension?

[h1]Dungeons![/h1]
As much I really liked this game, most of the dungeons have been recycled from the previous games. When you unlock new dungeons, they pretty much look almost like the exact same areas from the previous games and previous dungeons you've been to, except maybe some of them would have slight changes area wise, but that's about it. There's only a few unique dungeons in this game, like the ones in the Hyperdimension Planeptune where you're in a city and such. There should be more unique dungeons like those to keep the game fresh.

Most of the DLC from Victory are now free in Re;Birth 3 so that's a plus.

[h1]Plans![/h1]
Another additional feature regarding plans is that now finding the materials to make the plan is a lot easier. It will now tell you where you can find the materials you're missing, how you can get them, and what monster you need to defeat in order to get those materials. Now that's a huge plus!

[h1]Colosseum![/h1]
The Colosseum provides a challenge to the players that are looking for a challenge along with unique rewards. However one problem I've had was that the game would crash on me sometimes when I try to start a Colosseum battle. Other than that, everything else runs smoothly.



Phew! Now that was long!
[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
As a Neptunia fan, definitely! Looking for a good RPG? Get this and the other Neptunia games, they're really good RPGs.

9/10

[spoiler]P.S: Uni is the best waifu.[/spoiler]

19276996.review:
First thing I want to point out. This is indeed the best Neptunia game I have played so far compared to Re;Birth 1 and 2.

My reasons? It's because this game literally references back when Sega and Nintendo were fighting.
If you don't know ANY of this, you will NOT enjoy this. I repeat, if you seriously don't know about history between where Sega does what Nintendon't and when Playstation comes in to make both Sega and Nintendo's life hard, please don't say this game is bad because you simply don't understand what the creators tried to show here.

That was literally the purpose of this game. Though I'm only in chapter 3, I'm already laughing my butt off because of the references to these old consoles with their pathetic weaknesses. It also shows how old game companies used to live and die and if you did a lot of research, Neptunia references a LOT of game companies and of course other games.

If you have played the first 2, you'd love the fact that in the third installment, you don't have the SP gauge no more, in other words, no more worrying you'd run out of SP and instead, more beating up stuff. Sure it gets repetitive, but to complete the game, it's not that bad. Unless of course if you are like me who tries to 100% the game. I've 100% Neptunia 1 and 2 and trust me, it can get a little repetitive, but very worth it. I may change this review again after I finish the game, but I seriously enjoy this game too much already due to the references and better mechanics compared to the first and second. Take my advice if you are into retro games.

19273940.review:
The banter between the characters is as hilarious as ever.  I don't know who localized the dialogue for this entry into the Neptunia series but they really did an outstanding job here.  The banter alone really makes this game worth playing.  

Combat is flashy and fun to watch.  There is a fair amount of depth to developing your characters if you so choose.  Stats are influenced by discs, shares, different armor sets but it's not really necessary to beat the main story.  If you choose to beat the extra end game bosses however min/maxing your characters even at max level is going to be required so there is some challenge there to be had.  With that said it is a JRPG so the actual combat boils down to selecting an attack and watching it happen so if thats not your cup of tea this may not be for you.

The english voice overs aren't complete as with previous games but you can switch to Japanese in the menu.

Major con is a bug that causes the game to freeze and crash.  A fix has been posted by users but unfortunately IF/Compile have not released an official patch to address the issue.

19251580.review:
Overall, I am really enjoying this game.

IMO this is a great JRPG. The turn based battle system is great and even makes the minimal amount of grinding seem enjoyable. There is not a lot of strategy in the battles, which I liked since some JRPGs can be quite complex. The character animations are quite nice as well ;)

For those looking for adult images, etc, this game may not be for you. The characters are all cute (in that anime way) and you can play as Neptune in a swimsuit if you wish (hehe), but that's as far as it goes.

The story initially is very good, but unfortunately starts to get a bit boring mid-way through the game with long run-on dialogue, some of which does not move the plot forward at all. The story strongly depends on Neptune who is constantly shaking things up (in a good way) and Iris Heart for her... umm... being herself? The dialogue is certainly humorous, but there seem to be a lot of references that I ended up not understanding (perhaps from my lack of knowledge of other Japanese games?), which was mildly frustrating, but they seem to not be vital to understanding the story, just side-notes. 

The dialogue is voice acted nicely, but I found that only the main dialogue scenes are voice acted, while the rest is just text. Although I suppose this makes sense from a dev point of view (less work, money), I found it strange that one scene can be voice acted while in the next scene later on, I had to read the text. Imo this takes away from the immersiveness of the game.

But really, I was surprised I could play this game at all. With the min specs of 2.66GH CPU and 1GB GPU, my laptops specs were just a bit over half of this. And it was actually playable! Unfortunately, there is no option to turn down the graphics settings that I have found (possibly due to it being a port). As many have claimed, there are infrequent crashes that WILL occur, but in my case they are bearable, they just cause me to save more often than I normally would.

Overall, I would certainly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys JRPGs. It has that nice JRPG feel to it , despite the few flaws and bugs that are present. 9/10

And with all nice things, there comes with terrible things about this game as well. Most of my complaints are in of a more mechanical nature, the engine or system itself. So pardon, which in itself is a good thing, most of the time. 

As of 11/20/2015 these issues have not been addressed yet so a warning and heads up but don't let it deter you too much. 


-Its poorly optimized. At times you will crash due to the game not utilizing and allowing the game to allocate memory as needed. There is a workaround but this should honeslty not be necessary. 

-Poor framerates at times. I Have a top end GPU, a XFX DD R9 290X 4gb and I can barely get above 30 frames in some of the levels. I'm not sure what causes this one but its rather infuriating at times. You might not care but it does for me. It could be the fact taht the game itself is not utilizing all the 4 cores of my i5 2500k and what not, which is oftne the case as lot of games now a days are CPU bottlenecked rather than GPU assuming you've been keeping your comp sorta up to date.

And then we have the more ambigious thoughts where they don't really fall into either category.

? Your parents may disown you.


Overall thought: 

Great game from a great series with loveable girls with delicious yuri undertone but sadly plagued with poor optmization and okay port. 

9/10-  I would give it a solid 10/10 but the mechanical problems docked off a point. Not a big problem but definitely something that should be addressed in the future games. 

I would still highly reccommend it either way. Just know what you're getting into.

19181659.review:
note: the time displayed is incorrect, as my computer isn't constantly connected to the internet. I've clocked over 35 hours in the game according to the save file.

So, a return to the Hyperdimension Series. Frankly, as far as i'm concerned, Compile Heart and Idea Factory (US)/Marvelous AQL (EU) can't pump out these games fast enough. Each is good in its own right. 

Do note that if you're expecting a serious plot with high drama then this is not the game for you.

Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 3 returns to the universe first introduced by Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 2 and sees the characters of that universe once again battling the forces of piracy in abstract form. However, where Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 2 tackled this basic plot in a rather anvilicious manner, R3 is altogether a better game. This is largely because of the reinclusion of Neptune as the main character and the antics she brings to the table; the Hyperdimension Series has never been about the story itself, but about the interaction with the characters that the writers bring to the table, and their interactions with each other. As such, HDN: R3 improves upon the formula introduced by the first game in almost every way but one: combat. 

Part of the fun, personally speaking, was being able in HDN: R1 to pull off insane attacks with little effort. R3 attempts to curb this "abuse" by making EXE attacks both unlockable via achievements and require most--if not all--of a character's SP. Until you get the "drill" disc modification in the latter stage of the game, this heavily limits tactical options, as maintaining one's SP in battle becomes a chore in its own right.

an additional criticism of mine would be the game's performance even on relatively new machines. While the game is advertised as being playable at 60fps on 1080p resolutions, the reality is that the game presently locks itself into certain framerates and resolutions. with 8 gigs of ram, a dual core i7 5500U, and an AMD Radeon R9 M275--capable of getting upwards of 40 frames on fallout 4 at 720p and 50 frames on Warthunder on high settings at 1080p, I get a measly 27-30 frames on HDN;R3 at a locked resolution of 1280x720. Either due to a function of bad drivers or poor port-programming, all of the games in the HDN: R series perform poorly on systems which are well above the listed specifications. This may in part due to the games running heavily off of the CPU and not really using the GPU at full capacity.

In sum:

Pros:
-more nep
-shinier prettier graphics
-more of the parody and cute girls doing cute things that the fans have come to expect.
-more replayability

cons
-poor performance graphics-wise
-combat system has been poorly revised, and fails to add tactical depth
-annoying achievements to unlock potentially crucial character abilities
-limited post main-plot-arc content; sequel hook seems like an afterthought

Overall Score: 
8 neps out of 10.

19178263.review:
This game has a niche target audience so I'll do my best to outline it below. If i have to give a rating I would give it an 8/10 and reccomend getting it on sale. I'm very aware that while I enjoy these games reccomending them is a bit dodgy as alot of people simply will not like what this game is. It does what it tries to do but that wont appeal to ALOT of people.



REASONS NOT TO BUY THIS GAME:
This game is not mechanically deep, characters roles are pretty simple to figure, beyond buffs debuffs and manipulating the turn system theres not alot to learn, the last one is a nice touch but still not a good game for someone who wants to think hard about their strategy.

Story is pretty poor in general (though not even close to as bad as rebirth 2 imo) and it has alot of repetition in monsters, dungeons etc. 

The game is rated 12+ and that age level seems appropriate so if you're looking for adult images, look elsewhere. Fanservice is tame and sporadic.

It has quite alot of post game content through the free dlcs but unfortunately there is pretty much no way to progress to the last 4 areas or higher level fights in a  natural way. To do these you simply turn on the "in-game power level hax" and grind levels for an hour or two. This means that to keep things fun post game you have to carefully balance your levels or else you will be annihilated/untouchable.

The difficulty is a bit low for alot of the games until you reach the ultra late-game at which point it reaches stupid levels and the only way to balance is essentially to be really careful about how you break the game (see above point)

The 4th wall gets SMASHED repeatedly here. All the games broke the 4th wall but this one just completely ignores to the point where even I got annoyed in later chapters and I'm normally immune to it.

REASONS TO BUY THIS GAME:
The games characters are the main draw. Its a mix of a visual novel with a turn based rpg and the characters keep the visual novel element highly entertaining for the most part. Having all the dlc characters active can make it a bit too much dialogue wise so I reccomend not using them for a first playthrough if you intend to do more than 1. Some of the characters might drive some people crazy and as obvious as it might sound, anime like characters and reactions are plentiful so if you like anime you probably have a higher chance of liking this though I'm sure its not necessary. [Spoiler] Having plutia and Nep as the 2 of the 3 main characters pretty much makes this game for me. [/Spoiler]

Is funny.... well I think so anyway :D

The battle system while simple is fun to play and the animations are really smooth. If you have played the other games you have a good idea whats going on but this one is a step up on this front, not anything massively different just little things that make game more fun to play. The entire interface is massively improved in this game too, it still has its flaws but the menu in this game alone is enough to make it the best of the three.

Theres a challenge system introduced where you get little bonuses by completing challenges and while some of them are a little painful and the higher targets in many are RIDICULOUS, its still a nice addition.

The game isnt too short at about 40-60 hours for a casual playthrough of true ending if you read everything, certainly not long by rpg standards but long enough that you wont feel ripped off.

19119194.review:
Here is my Neptunia Re;Birth 3 review :) 

I will start by saying the Nep and her friends are back in tossing 30-minute to hour-long chats which plays out like a visual novel with RPG elements.

The good :) 

~Seeing more of this series coming over is a nice thing. 
~Being able to have all the DLC at once instead of waiting for it in pieces is nice. 
~Plutia and Neptune are amazing
~Scouts are gone, replaced with Stella's Dungeon.
~Battles are handled extremely fast.

The Bad :(

~The conversations and events can easilly last 30 minutes to an hour without seeing any actions. 
~The dungeons are frequently reused with different sets of enemies. 
~There is a lot of dialogue, but there is not as much voice acting as the first game...which is what I love to see. 
~I would have loved to see dialogue which would poke fun at the fact that the characters are in a 'new game+' 
~Battles are really about overpowering enemies and not truly using that many tactics. 
~DLC Characters are extremely overpowered until around Chapter 6 - 8. 

~GLITCH: Very rarely, if a player had played for many hours...sometimes the game would crash entering battle. 

The truth when taking Global Steam Stats into account: 

The game maintains an "Overwhelmingly Positive" review considering its a port and slight remake of the 2012 game Neptunia Victory. However at the time of this writing: 

~Only 80% of the playerbase chose to start the game. 
~Only 52% of the playerbase completed the prologue chapter. 
~Only 47% of the playerbase completed the first chapter.
~Only 37% finished the second chapter. 

~Less than 5% of the playerbase had the resolve and endurance to finish the game and actually see the ending(s).

If one knows a little bit of math, one can say that out of the people who actually have played the game (80%), of that total population....we can write 52/.8 = 65. Basically two thirds of those who started the game went through the prologue chapter at most. However, when the math is applied....by the end of Chapter 2, less than half of the people who actually started the game) actually remained playing the game passed the second chapter. 

The game is really for the playerbase who actually likes a combination of Visual Novels mixed with RPG interfaces in its own game. I love the game for its humor in a time where most games are super-serious and humorless, but even I admit that when I started the game to show my fiancee how the game started...it took an hour to go through the prologue chapter because most of it were the two of us reading it. 

I am currently going through the New Game+ attempting to get the TRUE ENDING after getting the Good Ending. :) I am one of the few who actually went through the entire game ;) 

Get this game if you have the patience to read a ton for a lighthearted, lukewarm story :) This game reminds me of games like Xenogears that beat out final fantasy in acquiring the award for "most ridiculous amount of text" in a scene. :)

19113104.review:
Full review here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mg9r4fuyLHU

Well that was fast, the third installment in such a short period of time, Idea Factory must put a lot of changes into there games, or do they? Here's the run down, each area of Gamindustri has it's own CPU and CPU candidate that looks over each area. This time around however, you aren't going around collecting the mascots power or anything like that, instead (Spoiler warning) Neptune gets sent to an alternate dimension that is in the 80's (Y'know, when cassets where still a big thing for games) and must find her way back to her dimension while at the same time, helping that dimension with it's problems. As always, you can expect a lot of references to the actual game industry, videos games and anime while poking fun at them. It's a series that loves to reference everything it possibly can but if that's not your thing, you may find the comedy to be a bit dull or repetitive.

Similar to the other games, it feels very JRPG esc so there is little you won't be familiar with. It leads me to think if Idea Factory will ever do anything different from the other Neptunia games since almost every aspect of this game is identical to the others that are currently available on Steam. I sometimes like to think it's a "Stick to what you know and what you can do" situation but that can sometimes come off as being lazy or re-using assets, since there's hardly anything different about this game compared to the others, apart from new characters and story. Briefly onto the options menu, there's hardly one again but on the plus side, the game does run at a solid 60FPS.

Yet again, the dungeons themselves aren't anything to write home about since they're fairly small with some consisting of several floors. They're pretty standard dungeons, as far as JRPG's go and don't have much in the way of exploration, just a small amount of enemies littering the area and random items and material dotted around. You would think that they'd do something more with the dungeons, since many JRPG's do but you gradually grow bored of exploring them since there's hardly anything to explore.

Moving on to the combat, there's practically nothing different here except for one change. Previously, you had to fill a guage everytime you entered a dungeon to pull off an EX finisher at the end of your combos by fighting enemies and would empty the moment you left the dungeon. Now however, your EX finishers are tied to your overall SP guage which makes the combat more enjoyable, albiet a bit easy. The games focus is it's strategy elements while being fast passed at the same time. In each battle, each character and enemy takes there turn when it's there's (Duh) so both you and the enemy can move each of your characters around the battle arena and position them carefully to get the most out of the battle. During one characters turn, you have multiple options for what you can have her do but only specific characters can do one special thing. There's: 

Attack,
EXE skills,
Defend,
SP skills,
HDD on/off,
Switch, 
Item,
Flee.

Whichever one you pick (Apart from HDD) will consume the characters turn and move to the next one in line. If you choose attack (Which you'll do a lot of the time) you are given the option to choose between three attacks that are tide to one of three buttons. These allow you to do different attacks which will have different effect but once you pick one, it'll move onto the next attack tab. Break focuses on depleting the enemies guard which if you accomplish that, the enemy will take more damage till it's there turn. Power which focuses on dealing damage and rush focuses on filling your SP guage. It leads to you having to mix and match your attacks together to deal with an enemy faster and effectively. The rest are pretty self explanatory apart from HDD on. Characters who are CPU's or CPU candidates have the ability to transform in the middle of battle, which increases there states but use up 20% of the SP gauge. Since it doesn't have any downsides to using it, you'll more then likely use it a lot of the time. Also, characters who aren't CPU's can also do there own transformation called Awaken which does practically the same thing.

As I've previously stated many times before and the main part of these games that I love so much is the art style. I adore how the environments are done, as well as how the characters are designed. Each are just so gorgeous to look at, they're colorful, bright and the way the colors blend together is fantastic. Speaking of the characters, we are introduced to a new character who goes by the name Plutia and I have to say, I find to her to be quite enjoyable. Her naiveté and simple minded attitude to almost everything everyone says is one of the amusing things. But, I wouldn't get on her bad side as she can also go HDD and that leads to her becoming sadistic. It can lead to some really creepy dialogue but I find it to be quite enjoyable.

At the end of it, I still find this to be quite an enjoyable experience, it's comedy focuses on referencing things from video games and anime and poking fun at them for there tropes and problems without it getting old. It's combat is very strategy focused and fast passed which is what I enjoy, leading to you blasting through each battle one at a time. Each character is unique in there own way and have there own personalities and characteristics that suit them perfectly, but also, because of who they are it can lead to a lot of mishaps and occasional funny moments to happen. It may disappoint some people though with how it is practially the same as the others with very little difference's. As some people have pointed out, it's like you're paying for the same game again just with a different story.

It's repetitious & grindy as hell, has a lot of dumb references & jokes mainly relating to video games, almost all enemies and dungeons are recycled like no tomorrow, [strike]many locked dungeons and items can be missed on one playthrough thus must be retrieved on another because a lot of them can only be unlocked when you already have the plans (schematics) for unlocking them in a specific chapter (2)[/strike]. However screw all that because it's got Nep-neps. 

[url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/Anitude/recommended/351710]But now...[/url]

[list]
[*]You can have 4 members in your party
[*][strike]There are a buttload of new endings which are mostly actually just extra scenes after the credits[/strike]
[*]Lily ranks [strike]and EXE Drives[/strike] are introduced much earlier 
[*][strike]A lot more new potential waifu party members are available for a choosin'[/strike]
[*]A little "mini-game" where you send someone off to a dungeon for a period of time where they barely bring anything useful to you. (This little feature also presents a ginormous pain-in-the-fanny achievement.) [/list]
[/quote]

This time now...

[list]
[*] The base game itself is a bit harder even without the difficulty altering, meaning that not being properly prepared can get you killed pretty fast
[*] The SP bar is also now your EXE gauge which makes EXE drives more troublesome to use but requires you to think a bit more on when to actually use them
[*] Character specific EXE drives are unlocked via in-game achievements per character 
(via "Challenges" like "run a certain distance, jump this many times, etc.")
[*] All of the previously released DLC (with the exception of the one in the Steam store) is included
[*] Every character available for use in the previous Re;birth games are here
[*] Some of the side scenarios are out of order as if they don't belong in a specific chapter
[*] Only three endings are present this time around (Normal, Good, & True)
[*] Stella's Dungeon is relatively easier, even without cheating with the system clock
[*] Shares are no longer relevant to the gameplay even though there's still a bar that shows them
[/list]

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=547317661

English voice actors still suck and the audio should still remain in Japanese.

Because the localization regarding the translation is rather ass and often looks like it tries too hard to be funny you could try waiting for the Neptunia re-translation mods coming out soon that replaces the current game's text with more accurate & less cringe-inducing translations. (Re-translation mod for Re;birth 2 is already out)

19033001.review:
[h1] Third time's the charm (?) [/h1]

Fan's rejoice - the third game of Neptunia is here! Other gamers take a peak - another anime-style JRPG is here!
But is it a plain copy of the previous two games, or maybe it had some major improvements that makes it the best (Neptunia) game so far?

[b][i] Story [/i][/b]

Re;birth 3 once again places the player in the Gamindustri world, ruled by [url=http://ideafintl.com/rebirth3/#/chara]Goddesses[/url]. Each rule a nation that represent a console company (Lastation -> Playstation, Leanbox -> Xbox, and so on) All seem peaceful after [i] the events of Re;birth 2[/i], but our lazy and goofy main character just had to get herself in trouble again, didn't she?

 The story is of the same pace as the previous games - it doesn't take itself too seriously, with it's long-winded boobie talk just before a serious boss battle, obscure gaming references at every single corner and blunt 4th wall breakings (The main character lives just to break it). But even so, Re;birth 3 probably tells  the longest and most decent story out of the 3 so far, which I personally enjoyed greatly. But do take note, that if it's a story-driven RPG you're looking for, you might need to rethink if this is what you're after.

[b][i] Gameplay [/i][/b]

The game's battle system remains mostly unchanged. It's still the typical turn based JRPG battle with the exception of being able to move the characters around for flanking and accurate special skill attacks (trust me it's much more simple than it sounds). The only change is the merge of SP bar and EXE drive bar, which is a healthy change. Before, you could just spam SP attacks and then finish it with very powerful EXE attacks. Now, you have to use SP for both specials and EXE attacks, so you have to play more smart.

The dungeon exploring remains mostly unchanged besides another very good change: the hidden treasure is no longer an invisible item in the dungeon that you had to spam a button to radar-search for it, it's now a mostly transparent Mario-type block that casts a shadow that the player can bump his head into for extra loot.

The levelling system finally feels balanced, the game doesn't suddenly throw in undefeatable mobs to get killed by, and you don't get too powerful too quickly (unless you use certain [i]Plans[/i]...)

The Chirper also returns which is a direct replacement to talking to NPCs in other RPG games. It basically has almost zero use besides getting references, funny thoughts and similiar things. Though for some players it might be something to look forward to during each chapter start.

And the fun auto-exploring Stella's dungeon minigame returns again. This time, with more stuff to do. And with faster exploring too, which is a plus too. And this minigame also solves the problem of farming for materials as you can get a lot of them from the minigame too, while doing something else. Like reading the plot.

Speaking of plot, you will be met by a lot of it. A lot of text that is. Sometimes it really pulls the player out of the action just to read dozens of lines of text. While story is important, from time to time you may feel as the "actual gameplay VS story reading" balance is off. Luckily you can still choose to skip the text relatively fast, or set it on AUTO, so you can read/listen to it while eating even!

Options. There are not many. You can switch the resolution, camera sensitivity, fullscreen mode, language and there are sound sliders. Also key bindings. Other than that there is not much to choose from.

And finally the Remake/Plan system, one of the highlights of Neptunia Re;birth's game mechanics for me. As before, it allows the player to "alter" how the game works. What that means is basically this is the unlock system. You want new dungeons? Unlock a plan and then gather materials to make a new dungeon. Need more items armor clothes etc.? Repeat what you did for the dungeon. And while this Remake system offers a lot of changes (Monster strength, BGM music change, Clothing, Stella's dungeon additions), it's not as hard to farm all the required materials for all the plans to unlock everything. Which is certainly nice. 
(Unless you're one of those people who need to unlock a "My waifu" accessory for all the girls, in which case farming is your problem, buddy!)

[b][i] Graphics and Sounds[/i][/b]

The game's as colorful as before, looks beautiful in 720p and higher, the character models remain unchanged and that's fine since they do look splendid. A first time player will certainly enjoy the way they look and move, while those who played the previous games might wish for more variety or change. The dungeons and monsters are also more or less the same, with some healthy additions, but a veteran player will certainly be bothered by enemy recolorings and same dungeon re-using.

All of the cast is fully voiced, with menu and overworld included. Only a few cutscenes are text-only. Each dungeon type has it's own BGM as it should, and boss fights have their own too, though some are re-used from previous games. I personally didn't mind it, as the music is not an annoyance in Re;birth games. 

[b][i] Japanese versus English [/i][/b]

The game originates from Japan as you may already know. But the cast is voiced both in japanese and english, which is quite awesome. The quality of both is superb so choose whichever you fancy more - squeaky typical-anime-ish japanese, or "dub" english. (Please don't take the "dub" part seriously)
The only minus I had with the localization is the fact that the translated story text is still full of          *achem* memes. It's not as bad as it was in Re;birth2 where you couldn't take the story seriously due to how the translation partakes the story in the wrong way. And trust me, when somebody tells you to "stabby stabby kill kill" another person while dramatic music plays, the experience is ruined. Luckily as I've mentioned, the translation got better and it's not as off, as it was before.

[b][i] DLC's & Bugs[/i][/b]

A surprise - the game comes with all DLC's besides the Stella dungeon goodie (which is still a very useful DLC). That means you get to use up to 28 instead of 10 characters if you wish. And grind up to 999th level instead of a measly 99.
The DLC characters get a few sub-stories which is a nice addition. And strangely enough they get more stories than in previous games where (most of them) were already in the game without DLCs.
You also get extra super equipment Plans. But if you don't want none of that you can always turn off the DLC's before starting the game, which is quite helpful for those who wish to do so. And whether you'll want to grind to the max is up to the player, as the extra dungeons do not introduce any more important story additions.

The game sadly comes with some bugs that don't allow players with low amounts of RAM or with certain Intel integrated graphic cards to play the game without crashes, so beware of that. Some are easily fixable, which is a relief as I myself had to find a quick fix for my own crash issue. I suggest reading up on any other potential game breaking issues before deciding to get the game as you may or may not encounter problems along the way.

[b][i]Final Verdict[/i][/b]

As a fan of the Neptunia series I was pleased by Re;birth 3: The game's performance got a boost. The story got a boost in length and quality. The gameplay was also balanced for a more enjoyable experience. And while the game still does not let go of it's habits of reusing old material, and it's grindy parts for the completionists, I feel that this game is certainly worth a try for both fans and those who enjoy a not-too-serious JRPG experience. Unless you're a very serious gamer who takes his games seriously, and you require a serious plot and seriously amazing gameplay I recommend this game. It's quite fun.

19022881.review:
Neptunia has always been one to tickle my funny bone. It's so lighthearted and fun that it keeps me coming back day and day again. Over previous titles, this one follows suit with some additions to the formula. EXE gauge has been eliminated from Rebirth1, instead integrating it into the SP gauge for individual players. The tactics are much more sound and require slightly more thought than before, but then again, I've been playing with all the DLC from the first carried over to here. SO, I am barely halfway through the game, but with 20 party members. The choices are so variable.

In total, I find the humor and story to be spot-on, and the antagonists are memorable spare for a couple. I can't help but feel sympathy for Copypaste, as I really like the direction he took later on. Also, Anonydeath has been a favorite of mine since I saw the anime. I cannot ever forget his top tier line. "My metal gear may be Solid Snake, but my heart's as maidly as they come." Priceless.

If you like JRPGs and graphic novels, this may hit a soft spot. Also, Neptune's constant spewing of references, whether you pick up on them all or not, kills me. No joke, I pretty much do that myself all the time. I enjoy this game thoroughly and hope to see the colisseum fixed soon.

I genuinely can NOT wait for Action Unleashed to be released on Steam. Since I don't have a PS Vita I am just dying to play a more active variant of a Neptunia game. AAAAAGH!!!

18990508.review:
Jogo MARAVILHOSO! Esse é um tipo de jogo para quem está jogando realmente para se divertir e não somente completar os capítulos, porque há muito para fazer mesmo depois que já se viu cada um dos finais. Para os fãs da franquia, este terceiro jogo é o mais completo dos anteriores, com muitas interações entre as personagens e é claro, muito Nep-Nep!!!

Uma gama enorme de personagens jogáveis (mais de 20) e a mesma deliciosa jogabilidade, música e humor dos jogos anteriores. Para fãs de animes, é um jogo obrigatório. Tenha certeza, é impossível não se divertir!

A Idea Factory/ Compile Heart mostram que jogos de primeiríssima qualidade não se fazem somente com altos recursos de gráficos e efeitos especiais. Fazem também pensando em elementos que traduzam diversão, com personagens carismáticos e com um apelo de proximidade; de maneira que pareça (e com certeza foi) feito exclusivamente para você.

E nisso, essa franquia é um exemplo de perfeição.

18944317.review:
If you loved the first one, you will ABSOLUTELY LOVE this one. Maybe because the protag was Gear-chan (too serious), but rebirth2 lacked a lot of the humor of the first game for like 80% of the game. This game definitely takes the best of the first game's tone and adds on a revamped UI and even more fun and humor. I'm only into ch 1 but I'm already in love with the game already!

I don't know if I would recommend slogging through game 2 to get all the references here, but upon doing so you'll really feel the engine improvement between this and games 1 and 2.

**EDIT 1: Into chapter 3, and there's a LOT of translation freedom here. It's a little hard to tell sometimes whether some things were intentionally mispelled or not.

**EDIT 2: I finished the game, and to sum it up:

+ A TON of content and new stuff to play with, and more characters than you'll know what to do with (all the DLC are included with this game except the one for stella's dungeon I think, which you should definitely get)
+ You'll definitely get all the references Rebirth1 had to this game, making it feel like you travelled in time.
+ Neptune is best protag. Plutia is love. Plutia is Life.
+ The UI and battle system is vastly improved. Everyone gets "CPU form" in a sense. Equipping a backline makes sense.
+ Stella's dungeon makes ingredient grinding much less grindy, and it's faster too and more interesting.
+ The difficulty curve is the smoothest of all 3 games. Haven't had any major grinding issues.
+ The story was better than 2. The writing was worse though. YMMV.
+ Eggplant scene.
+ The battle system has been heavily revamped in a sense. The EXE gauge has changed to a personal SP bar, and EXE drives were nerfed quite a bit. Slightly different system to play around with.

- The writing is really bad. Like, Rei-stuttering-inducing levels of bad at times. The overall plot is not bad though.
- The game feels a LOT longer to slog through for multiple playthroughs. Probably also due to all the loading screens inbetween areas.
- If you don't play with DLC characters you probably won't get a full party till the end of the True Ending path.


Best game of the 3 so far. Heavily recommend it. After playing this, going back to rebirth1 feels a bit like going back to a PS1 from a PS3.

18902515.review:
One of the best in the series in terms of story, some classic and touching 4th wall moments.   The Story continues off where MK2/Re;Birth 2 left off with Neptune being sucked into the UltraDimension and meets Plutia, the extreme Sadist CPU in the 16Bit Era.   

The Good;

The main story is perhaps the best out of the series, its very well told and the voice actors do a great job as usual in bringing our favorite nepneps back.   Also Re;Birth 3 improves on several features such as an improved treasure hunting system so no longer spamming 'scan' in order to find those treasure, or reloading the same dungeon over and over to find rare or important items.   

Also, I think its a positive change but others may disagree, they significantly changed how the SP system works, so now everything from healing spells, to the typical EX attacks use SP instead of previous games where special attacks/healing used mana and the EX had a seperate meter, its all combined now so some battles require a bit more strategy instead of just spamming the same attacks over and over. 

Another good point is the awakening system, which gives a large stat boost to non-CPU characters, along the same lines as a HDD transform. 

The Bad;

Now for the bad aspects,  unfortunately whilst the previous games mostly had limited bad points.  Victory//Re;Birth 3 does have several points which are quite negative and should be talked about, I will list these and explain them.

Ultra Extreme GrindFest (Worst in the Industry)

The developers incorporated new challenges into the game, by repeating the same process or achieving certain milestones, however they completely and honestly - went way over the top in terms of requirements for some of these,  such as jumping 10,000+ times... to unlock bonuses, I am not even kidding or lying how obnoxious some of these challenges can get,  luckily - no trophies are attached to them so for the most part, it unlocks stats/extra items or skills but still, it is way over the top considering these challenges are for each and every character in the game.

Another bad point is that the clothing has been priced far too high,  much much higher than the previous games so that all the unlockables and cute clothing are more or less a complete waste of time because by the time you've beaten the game, you'll still not be able to afford any of the clothing or accessories.  In fact,  getting money this time around is much harder than previous games.  In future games, I would like to see the clothing prices drastically reduced so that at least during the first cycle the player can at least purchase some clothing without skipping on upgraded gear. 

Another minor point is a few boss fights, especially end of game have ultra cheap moves which can insta-kill and even immediately game over if your unlucky or not sufficiently levelled high enough to wipe her out in one turn.

18895982.review:
Synopsis:
Anime clichés, a story with plenty of humour related to the gaming industry, fourth wall breaking, grinding for crafting unlocks, cuteness, boobs and panties. Sound interesting? If yes, you'll probably LOVE this game. If not, you'd better stay waaaay over there! No, a few more steps backwards ... there!

Bigger and better, Rebirth 3 takes the series back where it belongs.


Pros:
* Very funny (unlike Rebirth 2)
* UI and mechanics improvements over previous titles
* Bigger
* Best story in the series (so far)
* Friendly to people new to the series

Cons:
* Easy
* Lack of new moves
* Some 3d cutscenes still as low-res as in the previous ones


To me, Rebirth 2 felt lackluster after the first game. The story wasn't as funny or as long, and dialogue dragged on with neverending pointless Chirper messages. Rebirth 3 feels like it goes back to what Rebirth 1 was: hilariously funny and full of protagonist wackiness and fourth wall breaking. The story continues after Rebirth 2. It feels more developed, and thanks to its nature and Nepgear's helpfulness it's easily understood by new people to the series. All old characters in the series return as playable characters although all of them don't participate in the main story. There are also some great new additions to the cast.

There are several mechanics improvements which make me happy. EX and SP point systems have been merged which makes skill management a bit more interesting. UI in the menus have improved. Stella's Dungeon now has a friendly drop list for dungeons and monsters. The map is bigger, with multiple layers and screens, providing space for more dungeons. No more search spam for hidden treasures; they have a new mechanic and are spotted visually. Visuals are also slightly better. The gallery is big, there are plans for changing BGMs and old scenes can be reviewed.

Unfortunately at the point where I'm at, the game feels a bit too easy. When I played Rebirth 1 I didn't feel bad about turning on Easier Enemies. Now I feel like I want to turn on Harder Enemies instead. The combat doesn't offer as much to old players as it could. The old characters all seem to use their familiar moves. The graphics in some 3d cutscenes are blurry and low-res, which can probably be blamed on the PS VITA original.

I'm thoroughly enjoying this one! Jury is still out, but possibly the best in the series. Thumbs up!

18888335.review:
Rebirth 3, un jeu qui ressemble aux deux précédents avec des améliorations notables, des difficultés modifiées, on apprécie vraiment de ne pas avoir à fouiller sur des forums pour trouver les lieux de drop des items, le mini-jeu de Stella a lui aussi été amélioré, pour ceux qui se rappellent de Rebirth 2 on avait droit à un donjon qui mettait 24h à se terminer pour peu qu'il se termine complètement...
Ayant déjà joué à Fairy Fencer F, voir les challenges sur les personnages m'a fait comprendre à quel point ça allait être long, très long, si on veut tout faire, de plus il y a des plans sur certains challenges donc on se sent bien obligé de les faire.
On sent un peu la redondance avec les donjons et les monstres qui sont parfois des copies avec les deux précédents jeux, mais je pense qu'il ne faut pas se leurrer, si on joue avec Nep-Nep et sa bande c'est qu'on s'y fait et qu'on accepte de jouer pour l'histoire, d'ailleurs niveau textes j'ai l'impression qu'il y en a beaucoup plus que dans les précédents, c'est peut-être qu'une impression.
Pour les petits plus, on a droit à 11 pages de CG, sympathique pour les amoureux des designs de cet univers, il y a même un section vidéo qui nous permet de revoir les moments de l'histoire sans avoir à recommencer le jeu.
Je ne regrette pas vraiment pas cet achat, surtout qu'on me permet de jouer avec Noire <3, pour les plus acharnés avec les challenges, prévoyez à peu près 200h de jeu, il faudra être très patient.
Sinon après un troisième jeu, je remarque qu'il y a toujours ce même bug d'inception mais il faut croire qu'aucun patch sur les anciens jeux n'a aidé donc ça sera pareil sur celui-là.
Maintenant on a plus qu'à prier pour avoir un jeu de cette licence en 2016 vu l'historique des jeux qui laisse penser le contraire...
Les fans, il faut TOUT acheter !

Au fur à mesure qu'on joue on peut aussi sentir que le jeu est clairement mieux optimisé avec les DLC gratuits qui sont déjà inclus dedans, par exemple les skills, on doit progressivement monter des niveaux pour obtenir de puissants combos.

18875892.review:
Ich kann jedem, der die beiden vorherigen Teile gespielt hat und jetzt noch untentschlossen ist, ReBirth 3 wärmstens empfehlen. Es hat alles , was eine gute Fortsetzung braucht. Ein Pluspunkt ist definitiv, dass das Menü wesentlich aufpoliert und deutlich leichter zu handhaben ist als in den vorherigen Teilen.  Natürlich wartet Teil 3 auch wieder mit einer ordentlichen Story und jeder Menge schrägem Humor, sowie zahlreichen Anspielungen auf andere Videospiele auf. Absolutes Highlight waren diesmal für mich die teils altbekannten, aber auch die neuen Charaktere. Vor allem mit Neptune, unserer allseits beliebten Protagonistin und auch mit Plutia/Iris Heart gibt es Dialoge, wo ich mir vor Lachen manchmal eine Träne aus dem Auge wischen mußte.

Kleiner Negativpunkt ist jedoch, dass größtenteils die exakt selben Dungeons zum Einsatz kommen, die man schon aus den vorherigen Teilen kennt. Hier hätte ich mir mehr Einfallsreichtum bzw. Abwechslung gewünscht. Das bleibt im Großen und Ganzen aber auch das einzige, was es zu meckern gibt.

Fazit:
Hyperdimension Neptunia ReBirth3: V-Generation ist jedem Fan der Serie und solchen, die es werden wollen, nur zu empfehlen.

18874002.review:
《Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth》系列第三部作品正式於今年十月底移植到家用電腦平台，也成為Steam平台最受歐美玩家青睞的日系角色扮演遊戲之一，此篇評論是以第三作重製版本為基準。故事主角的重要職位從前作擔任女神候補生的涅普姬雅回到『紺紫之心』涅普迪努身上，數年前順利擊潰犯罪組織燒錄卡的涅普迪努，因為生活過於安逸而虛擲光陰成為廢材女神，某次接受公會委託時遭受神秘組織七賢者算計，穿越時空來到年份G.C.1989的遊戲業界，玩家會遇見同為紫國女神的『彩虹之心』普露露特以及仍未成為『聖黑之心』的黑國女神諾瓦露，為了回到原本的次元，涅普迪努尋求好友普露露特和諾瓦露的協助，希望能透過擊敗神秘組織七賢者，達到回到原本次元的目的。


本作玩法與前作相似，皆以章節式的故事述說方式將玩家引導到劇情的結局，破關一輪所需遊戲時數大約在二十小時上下，其他像是遊戲操作方式與玩法都跟前作大同小異，不過改變最大的一項設定是戰鬥系統，人物數值強度與計算公式做出更動，以前只要無腦提升人物命中與迴避，都能跟魔王慢慢耗到獲勝，現在命中迴避影響力被下修，玩家會明顯感受到基礎數值攻擊力、防禦力和生命值的重要性大幅提升。除此之外，連段系統也做了部分修改，Break Attack與Rush Attack傷害降低，大幅度提升Power Attack傷害，為三種連段技能造成的傷害做了平衡，不再只是無腦連刷Break就能破防秒殺敵人，反而更注重角色之間的配合，隊伍必須分配專門破防及輸出的角色，才能順利擊敗頭目等級的強敵。


《Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth3 V Generation》新增了第二作曾出現的新玩法『史黛拉地下城』，簡單來說就是扮演黑心老闆指派員工去幫自己做牛做馬的地城自動探索功能，玩家可以派遣史黛拉探訪地城，探訪時間結束後史黛拉會帶著獎勵向你回報，每次派遣史黛拉探索都會得到經驗值獎勵，等級較高也會帶來較好的獎勵，順帶一提，有時候探索完成時系統會提供隱藏地城、地城異動變化等各種資訊，玩家可以選擇相信或是不相信這項情報，而這項決定將會直接影響該地城出產的材料金錢和怪物種類。


另一項讓筆者眼睛為之一亮的新玩法，就是被稱為『女神情報站』的娛樂話題節目，玩家可以在這裡發現涅普迪努、普露露特、諾瓦露，甚至是象徵任天堂的白國女神布蘭都會登場，擔任主持人的女神們除了會向玩家推銷土產並釋出優惠讓你心動購買以外，還會出現有趣的連續發問有獎徵答單元，玩家如果成功答對所有問題就可以得到各式道具獎勵。需要特別注意各章節結束之後會有評價玩家行動的節目（會依照任務完成度、敵人擊破數量、取得信仰百分比決定），如果取得滿分的優秀評價，就會得到稀有道具作為獎勵喔！


《Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth3 V Generation》整體表現依然讓人滿意，雖然遊戲內容大量兼用前作人物建模與地圖場景設計，遊戲前期步調也過於緩慢，甚至逼迫玩家需要刷怪農道具解任務才能使劇情繼續發展，但是本系列作一直以來都不是將故事劇情與遊戲性當作是最大賣點，會購買本作的玩家無一不是被家機擬人化、獨特遊戲業界世界觀、對話全程聲優配音和服務粉絲的殺必死遊戲插畫所吸引。最後筆者想在文章末段對紫國女神『彩虹之心』普露露特說出一句話：「請您繼續鞭打我吧，我的女王大人！」


優點：
+變身前的普露露特好可愛，變身後的普露露特好性感。
+戰鬥系統改善前作單一屬性過強的缺點，增加了不少挑戰性。
+新增史黛拉地下城與女神情報站等新玩法，即使破關後還是令人意猶未盡。


缺點：
-前期需要農怪刷道具觸發劇情，讓人感到些許的厭倦感。
-怪物建模與地圖場景設計多數跟前作一樣，除了進行微調以外其餘照搬。


結論：少數到三代還能讓粉絲毫無怨言買單的優質作品，破除三代魔咒謠言。


網誌圖文好讀版：
http://mgrim214.blogspot.tw/2015/11/hyperdimension-neptunia-rebirth3-v.html

18861856.review:
So I've been playing this for a while and decided to do a detailed review for this game. (Since I can't make a funny one, hehe)

I played Re;birth1 and Re;birth2, simply put Re;birth3 is by far the best one in terms of everything. Unlike Re;birth2 that almost feels like the exact same Re;birth1 but played with other characters (the CPU Candidates), Re;birth3 has quite different features than the other two such as a slightly different battle system, different dungeon hidden treasure, different GUI, different World Map, and etc.

Though it is better than the previous games, Re;birth3 is back to having that same game design flaw with Re;birth1 that is having less party slot from the total of main characters. Re;birth1 mistake is that you only have 3 character slots while having 4 CPU goddesses, meaning you have to leave out 1 unfortunate CPU goddess in your party. Re;birth2 fixed this with having 4 slots for 4 CPU Candidates. But Re;birth3, while you now have 4 slots, the number of main CPU goddess is now 5 (or 6 if you want to count in [spoiler]Peashy[/spoiler]). Yes, this isn't gameplay wise, but having to leave out one main character is painful.

Another problem that I have with the game, though not fatal but still bugs me, is how the optional events works for DLC characters, I won't spoil the content of the event and which one, but just expect a chronological order failure with it. In other words, the DLC events is not in sync with the main storyline.

Re;birth3 is back with CPUs as main protagonists, but with Noire, Blanc, and Vert have a slightly different personality as this game takes place in a different dimension from the previous game (while still being a direct sequel of Re;birth2). So have fun with Neptune being Neptune, Noire's arrogant tsundere, Blanc's raging attitude, and the now keep bragging about her chest, Vert. To make things better, Re;birth3 is introducing a new main character named Plutia, which personally I find it the best one from the five, play the game if you want to know why.

I haven't finish the whole game, but it seems the game is no longer shares-based, which might be nice to some of you that gets really really bored doing quests to control shares to aim for a specific ending like Re;birth2. [spoiler]Interestingly, Neptune comments about this in the game.[/spoiler]

The game has a new optional feature called Challenges that basically an in-game achievements that grants additional bonuses or a Plan on completing it, for instance, jump 100 times and you get a permanent stat bonus. Though, it's too bad that the challenges are not global but attached to a single character, so you have a same bunch of the achievements that progress individually for each of the characters in the game.

Plans is more neat now, as you no longer have that annoyingly item change and add enemies plans from ciphers each time a new dungeon pop up. And the dungeon change is simplified for the greater good as it is basically only change the boss monster in the dungeon, making you easier to remember where to get material items since the regular monsters stays the same.

Stella Dungeon mini game from Re;birth2 is back although slightly different than the previous one. But worry not as the changes is for the better, you can access Stella's Dungeon in the menu now which is very very nice, and I think it is generally takes a much less time than Re;birth2 one, especially if you buy the DLC that made the floor search only takes 1 second to complete which make 100 floors Area only takes 1 minute and 40 seconds to complete.

Conclusion is that Re;birth3 is the best Neptunia Re;birth series ever made. I'll happily recommend this game to someone, though it is hard to recommend this without recommend them the previous games, especially Re;birth2 since the game is often referencing the events of Re;birth2 although not really a big deal to the game's storyline.

O yeah, I forgot to mention that this game is more HD than the previous games.
